March 8th, 1948.

Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your Requisition #76004, File 15-3 man. This has to do with the installation of a Warm Air Heating System at Griswold. We have supplied one of our furnaces, through Messrs. Neale, Stothard & Chapman, of Brandon. Piping has been made up as per your specification and we understand will be installed in that manner by the Heating Contractor. The proper furnace has been supplied against the specification shown in your file but we are somewhat worried about the inadequate distribution of piping that is being installed in this system.

The Plan calls for a total of 1,041 sq. in. of warm air piping and 402 sq. in. of return air piping. There should not be such a large spread, as you will find that it will be impossible to deliver the amount of warm air shown with such a small amount of return air connected to the furnace. This matter, we believe, was taken up through your local office and instructions received that the job must be installed as shown in the plan. The Heating Unit cannot give the best of service unless equal distribution of air is taken from same. Therefore, we are placing ourselves on record that the job is being installed as specified, but the furnace cannot be expected to last for the normal period under these conditions. There will be times in very cold weather when the furnace will be fired to the limit but free circulation will not be possible without extra return air connections.

We have offered, on more than one occasion, to submit up-to-date free service and layouts for buildings of this nature. The main reason, as you will understand, is that we want our furnaces to give the best satisfaction possible, which in the long run is a recommendation for quality and efficiency in the heating plant.

Trusting that you will accept the information given with our friendly wish that warm air heating equipment supplied to your buildings may give the best service possible.

Yours truly,

CLARE BROS. WESTERN LIMITED.

O.J. Hatch
Manager

OJH/JM
March 13th, 1948.

Memorandum: Indian Affairs Branch.

Re: Purchase Order 24392

Please find herewith copies of a letter from Clare Brothers Western, Limited, Winnipeg, who supplied Stothard & Chapman, Brandon, Manitoba, with the furnace for Oak River Indian Day School, as per above purchase order.

The manufacturer's letter is self-explanatory. Please furnish them with the information requested, sending us a copy of your reply, or supply this office with the necessary details to enable us to reply to their letter of the 8th instant.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.
Ottawa, March 18, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Purchase Order 24392

We have your memorandum of the 13th instant, file 76004-15-3 Man., enclosing copy of letter received from Clare Brothers Western Limited, Winnipeg, regarding the furnace.

We ordered the furnace and other necessary equipment for it as contained in the bill of materials for one class room school, supplied by the Lands and Development Services Branch.

We are forwarding them a copy of the letter which you received from Clare Brothers Western Limited and as soon as they reply you will be further advised.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD
Ottawa, March 18, 1948.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Oak River Indian Day School,
Province of Manitoba.

This school is under construction and we ordered through the Departmental Purchasing Agent a Gurney heavy duty model furnace and also the other necessary attachments for the furnace as outlined on page 10 of bill of materials for standard combined one room Indian day school with teacher's quarters.

For your information I enclose copy of a letter received from Clare Brothers Western Limited who obtained the contract to supply and install this furnace.

I would appreciate it if you would let me know as soon as possible what answer we should give the firm.

Director,

PP/EGD
Ottawa, March 23, 1948.

Re your letter File 204-11 A.G. dated March 9th re new Oak River Day School:

The Oak River Day School will not be completed by the end of March. Mr. Robertson, Carpenter, thinks it will take at least until the end of April to complete it, including the outside painting. Thus we would need $1000.00 more for labour.

There has been no contract let as yet for the installing of blinds throughout the building.

The plans also call for a Chemical Toilet, with inner pail. We would also need app. 18 ft. of vent pipe. 3" galv.

We will also need a cistern hand pump, and eaves-troughing.

Memorandum

Re: Oak River Indian Day School,
Province of Manitoba.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of March 8th bearing your notation of the 19th instant, together with copy of a letter from Clare Brothers, Western Limited, with reference to the above, you are advised as follows.

The gravity warm air heating system for the above has been designed to meet a somewhat different set of requirements than is usually the case. It may be briefly stated that the Classroom space is of prime importance and has been worked out to provide for a satisfactory distribution of the heat according to the design principles laid down by acknowledged authorities.

The Cloakrooms and Teacher's Quarters have been provided with warm air leaders and registers only. This is due in part to the difficulty in getting returns back from these rooms, and also having in mind that when the Classroom and basement space is unoccupied, at least three of the four dampers in these leaders will be throttled or shut off.

Under such circumstances, it is felt that the furnace will not be penalized, and that the system can be counted on to give the desired results if installed as shown.

We appreciate the friendly criticism received, and the foregoing reply is written in the same spirit.

Proposed Peguis South Day School

Proposed Lake St. Martin Day School

Oak River Day School.

During his recent visit to the Department Mr. Indian Agent Young advised that he was completely satisfied with the work of Mr. John Robertson of Kenton, Manitoba, in erecting the Oak River School. It is therefore suggested that Mr. Robertson be approached to ascertain if he is interested in building another school for us on the same basis.

Included in our 1948-49 estimates are one-room schools and attached teachers' residences for Lake St. Martin in the Portage la Prairie Agency and Peguis South in the Fisher River Agency. It is recommended that Mr. Robertson be approached concerning these schools. They would be identical with the one he is now finishing at Oak River.

It would require two or three months to obtain the standard bill of materials for these schools. Therefore we are trying to line up our building programme now, before there is too much contracting activity.

I might add that we have found that the day labour basis of building, as adopted at Oak River, has proven cheaper than the cost plus basis contract, as used at Murdoch in the Fisher River Agency. While we have not yet the final cost...
figures, it is evident that the Oak River School will cost less than the Murdoch School (these buildings are identical).

From the map it would seem evident that Mr. Robertson would be more likely to be interested in the Lake St. Martin School rather than in the Peguis School. Therefore Mr. Lazenby should advise if there is any good carpenter interested in the Peguis School on a day labour basis.

Blueprints, specifications and bills of materials for the standard one-room school with teacher's residence are being sent, along with this letter to the two Agents concerned.

Thorough mixing or working produces the correct consistency. (c) Mix for only one blackboard at a time.

(d) Place gobs every 12 inches in horizontal row along center of slab lengthwise and two (2) extra at each edge at joints. (Figure 4).

THE INSTALLATION OF STERLING BLACKBOARD

1. Immediately slide slab into position and equalize space at top and bottom, applying pressure over cement gobs.

2. Immediately put clamps in place and insert wedges over the cement gobs to hold slab in proper contact with the cement and wall. Two or three light weight clamps are sufficient for each slab, (Figure 5). Wrap the wedges in paper to protect the blackboard surface.

3. Drill holes along top of blackboard every 16 to 18 inches and countersink for wood screws.

4. Screw slab securely to top ground—using a \( \frac{3}{4} \)" No. 8 flat headed wood screw countersunk, (Figure 6).

5. Insert metal rustproof joint at right end to receive next slab.

6. Proceed with second and successive slabs.

7. When space along one wall is finished it should appear as in Figure 7. Clamps should be left overnight. One metal direction plate (for each room) must be attached to the wall adjacent to the blackboard, in a prominent place when installation is completed. These are included in the envelope with directions which is posted on back of blackboard. (Figure 11, page 4.)

8. After the cement has been allowed to set at least 10 hours, (over night) take off clamps. Then place quarter round or cove mouldings at top and bottom of blackboard to complete the installation. These mouldings must be toe-nailed as tightly against the surface of the blackboard as possible.

9. "Break in" blackboard as instructed on metal plates. (Figure 11, page 4.)
Cutting the Blackboard to Fit the Spaces

Place a straight-edge (Figure 8) or the cutting clamp on the back of the slab of Sterling Blackboard exactly where the break is desired (Figure 8). With any sharp instrument, preferably the W.C. Special rapid cutting tool or the handle end of a file sharpened, score the back surface along the straight-edge five or six times being sure to score it well at the edges of the slab. (Figure 8.)

Turn the slab over and score it on the face side just as was done on the reverse side. Then with constantly increasing steady pressure bear down on the slab of blackboard to be broken off until the break occurs. (Figure 9). The slab will break true.

Marking the Blackboard for the Proper Spaces

Stock lengths of Blackboard should be used to fill the spaces (i.e., for 12-foot spaces, use 2 six-foot slabs). Where stock lengths do not fill the space evenly, use the proper stock lengths so that the "fill in" slab will be no less than 3 feet long (i.e., for 12 foot space, use two 6 foot slabs; or for a 9-foot space, use one 5 ft. and one 4 ft. slab; or for 11 foot 6 inch space, use one 8 ft. and one 3 ft. 6 in. slab, etc.)

The slabs should be "set" into the space temporarily and the last piece cut to exact length (Figure 10). Proceed with the cutting.

Breaking in and Care of Blackboards

Blackboard must be properly "broken in" before it is used.

1. With the side of a piece of crayon, chalk the entire writing surface. Avoid chalk with a glazed surface.

2. Work the chalk into the surface of the board, using a good quality felt eraser for the purpose.

3. Repeat Nos. 1 and 2.

4. Clean the board with a soft, new cotton cloth or with a good quality chamois and your board is ready for use.

CAUTION

Never, never use any of the "treated" cloths or chamois which are advertised for use on the blackboard. They invariably contain oil in some form and their continued use will impair the efficiency of the blackboard writing surface. Do not wash the board with water or with blackboard cleaning solutions. Use only clean cotton cloths or good quality chamois free from animal fats.

IMPORTANT

(Aluminum Instruction Plate, Figure 11)

Aluminum Instruction Plate for each room is supplied free of charge with every shipment of blackboard. They are included in the envelope posted on the back of the blackboards with the Installation Directions.

They should be tacked in place in every room containing blackboard on the blackboard frame near door jamb in plain sight of the person caring for the blackboards. If enough plates (one for each room) have not been included, write for an additional supply furnished free.

The Regular Method of Installing Sterling Blackboards

All necessary Sterling Cement for the installation of this board has been included with the shipment (one gallon for every 32 lineal feet). Additional cement can be ordered at nominal cost from the Weber Costello Company or its distributors.

BEFORE STARTING WORK CHECK EACH OF THESE POINTS CAREFULLY

1. Uncrate the blackboards—inspecting each slab carefully. If any are cracked or broken in transit, file claim against the transportation company.

2. Distribute the blackboard to each room and exact space. (Figure 2) making sure the slabs fit the spaces. (Figure 10).

3. If blackboard has been standing on edge uncrated for some time it may sag of its own weight and become slightly bowed. Heavier weight clamps and larger wedges must then be used to insure perfect contact between the blackboard, cement, and wall. The clamps also should be left on the blackboard for several days.

4. Inspect wall behind the blackboard.
   (a) The wall should be a good cement plaster.
   (b) Grounds should be set flush with the plaster. (Figure 1). If these are not provided, arrangements should be made with architect or contractor to have it done.
   (c) The plaster must be thoroughly dry.
   (d) If walls are painted or coated—they should be scraped down the center for solid cement contact.

5. Lay slab face down on a padded bench. (Made very easily by using one of the crates.) Wipe all dust and dirt off the back of the blackboard. Go over wall with a stiff brush and remove all loose particles of plaster and dust. (Figure 3).

6. Mix cement THOROUGHLY.
   (a) Sterling Cement No. 50 is included in every shipment of Sterling Blackboard. It is in form of a powder (in bags) and a liquid (in cans) which are to be thoroughly mixed on the job.

Further to my conversation with you of last month regarding the necessary renovation of the rooms in the Mission House on the Oak River Reserve, Griswold, used by your Department for many years as a school. Col. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,

Department of Mines and Resources,

Dear Col. Neary:

When you visited Brandon last, I mentioned to you the question of the repairs to our Mission House on the Oak River Reserve and you stated that this matter would be attended to but to date we have had nothing further on the matter.

The position is that these two rooms in the lower part of the Mission House were supplied free of charge to your Department for over twenty-five years as school rooms. We were glad to be able to provide these quarters but we did understand that they would be put back into shape for living quarters once they were no longer required for school purposes. You can well understand how the wear and tear of school desks and school children caused considerable delapidation which must be attended to before they will be suitable as living quarters again. We have submitted an estimate from a local contractor but would be quite willing for you to obtain your own figures or if you desire have the work done through your own Agency. We would, however, like to have this matter attended to as quickly as possible so that our Missionaries can have the comfort of the use of the house and after all, the school has been away from there since the end of last June.

With all good wishes for the New Year,

Yours sincerely,

Archdeacon of Brandon.
January 17, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Oak River School,
Portage la Prairie Indian Agency,
Province of Manitoba.

For several years on the Oak River Reserve, we have used the Mission House, which is owned by the Church of England, as a school. We have now erected a new school on this reserve and it will not be necessary any longer to use the Mission House. However, the Church authorities feel that we should put the building in the same condition as it was when we first started to use it. The estimated cost of renovating the building is $635.17, as shown in a copy of a letter dated September 14, 1948, from Reverend Canon I. A. Norris. (Please see letters attached).

Your approval of the expenditure of the amount mentioned above for renovating the Mission House would be appreciated, as our officials feel that we should meet the wishes of the Church authorities. This building was in service as an Indian school for a number of years and no rent was paid for such use.

Director.

Sir,

We have been trying for some time to secure a teacher for the Indian school at Oxford House, Keewatin, but find it exceedingly difficult to get a certificated teacher willing to go to one of these isolated posts. In order that the school may no longer be left vacant we are proposing now to send a supply in the person of Miss E.J. Armstrong, 17 Pembroke St., Toronto. Miss Armstrong has no certificate, and has not taught in any public school; but she has a good common school education, is a person of good judgment and excellent character, and I think would be quite competent to do the primary teaching required at a place like Oxford House till such time as we can find a certified teacher who is willing to go. As this school has been aided by the Department I deem it but right to submit these facts, and will await the concurrence of the Department before finally deciding the case. A prompt answer will oblige, so that a teacher is to go out this summer we may take advantage of the steamers on Lake Winnipeg as far as Norway House.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

A. Sitterthwaite
General Secretary.

Sir,

The Methodist Church established its mission at Oxford House about the year 1842 and has continued to do its work there until the present time and must have spent about one thousand dollars per year or a total of at least 60,000.00.

There is no other Church doing Mission work there and never has been in all the years.

The population is 310 and all belong to the Methodist Church with the exception of the Pagan element which might represent one hundred people. That is to say it is safe to count as members or adherents about 200 people.

The child population numbers 156 or 88 boys and 68 girls. Of these fully two thirds are not available as pupils owing to the distance at which they live from the Methodist Mission. A large number of the people live at Jackson Bay some 18 miles distant. This was the site of the original Mission Station. Some live along the shore of the lake which is thirty miles from south to north. The possible attendance at the Mission School is about 45 and the actual attendance at present averages 23.09 in the summer season and less in the winter when the Indians retire to their houses for shelter.

There are about ten houses within a radius of two miles from the Mission Church.

School has been conducted in the Church for some years and is being conducted there at present.
Here as at Nelson House the School building must be constructed of logs as the rate of freight is high being $6.00 per cwt. from Norway House, and 75 cents per cwt from Selkirk to Norway House. I would also recommend that the roof be covered with mica roofing, as Shingles are an impossibility owing to the cost of purchase and transport.

Nails doors etc will have to be purchased at Selkirk and shipped down but logs can be obtained on the shores of Oxford Lake and not more distant than 6 or 7 miles.

They are accustomed to build houses after the old Red River type at this point logs ten feet long jointed by grooved upright posts but I cannot recommend this style for in a very few years it will bulge at the posts and fall. I much prefer the house with dove-tail corners.

A school house might be built at Oxford House on the following approximate basis:

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Preparing Logs        | 100.00 |
| Sawing boards         | 100.00 |
| Erecting building     | 200.00 |
| Doors windows nails   | 30.00  |
| Roofing & freight     | 70.00  |
| **Total**             | **500.00** |

The Hudsons Bay Company will build if asked to do so.

The Missionary in charge should not be asked to do so because he is not a practical man.

It would be possible to send a practical man or men from Norway House under direction of the Agent.

I have the honor to be

Your Obedient Servant

John Summers

Inspector of Indian Agencies

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, in reference to the erection of a school-house at Oxford House and to thank you for your offer to assist the Department in the project.

The Department has no special specifications for a building such as it is proposed to put up at this point, but has in view a log school-house 24 feet by 20 feet with dove-tailed corners. There should be three windows on each side of the building and one entrance. It has also been suggested that mica roofing would be preferable to shingles. The floor should be of dressed lumber, and the building will be heated by a stove.

In addition to the above it will be necessary to provide two closets for the accommodation of the pupils.

In view of the experience that the officials of the Hudson's Bay Company have had in the erection of log buildings in these outlying districts it is thought that nothing more than a general outline of the nature of the building will be necessary to enable them to give a figure for the cost of construction, and the Department would be pleased to have an estimate with a description at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

C. C. Chipman, Esq.,
Commissioner,
The Hudson's Bay Company,

Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find report of this mission. Enclosed Dec. 31st, 1870. Hope it will reach you in time for publication. The same has been reached me about the middle of January, and as there has been no chance to send out yet, I have not got it away. I understand some surveyors of the N.P.R. Railway will be surveying soon, and will get it away then. In the meantime would call your attention to two or three matters connected with my work here. Have now been a long time in the Indian work, and consider myself quite at least - some little about it. When the Methodist Church disposed with my services at Wesley Boarding School upon the report of Mr. Perrin and Mr. Woodworth, I was quite satisfied to resign. What the history of that school was afterwards, and how long the administration which succeeded me, kept the school open, and with what success, you are all doubtless fully aware - at least by some extent. When the Indians brought me back to the Wesley Red School, and offered to pay me salary themselves, and the opposition I met with and labored against, being contemporaneous with Mr. Fletcham, you may not be very familiar with, and at least it matters not now. At least the Department were willing to pay my salary, and keep the school open until Mr. Perrin wrote me again 2 or 3 times asking me to come down to this district as missionary teacher. That is the reason why I am here today. Now regarding the work here I have been put very much disheartened in my efforts to teach the children, because of the lack of a decent school room and supplies.

These people are well disposed towards School work and would appreciate any thing done along the line of education for the young generation, and have felt so much ashamed at the lack of effort made, have sent a Deputation through the Young Men's Club. Will you please see that it is not cut down and that the activities mentioned are proceeded at once.

Then in the matter of disposing of the property and that the Debt has been paid off. Have no source of any kind to sell out, but left a means of everything disposed of. Have also seen a disposition to run which we need in the best way. We have had an awful amount of sickness, and have been kept constantly out of School hours. Since last September we have had a death. Have also had charge of the Nations here for the past six months. All of these duties added to that of Missionary has pretty fully occupied my time.

I have thought to ask of the Indian Dept. It is this: Would you be willing to add to our School Stationery when it reaches you 8 x 10 Writing Tablets ruled. No. 100 Envelopes. It is impossible to purchase Stationery in this Country, when I asked for three at a time, was refused. So my last request upon the grounds that they were not supplied to Day Schools. If you could favor me in this way I should feel extremely obliged.

I have for the honor to subscribe myself,

Your obedient servant,

John Macleod

Re School

At present they are using the Methodist Church as a school, but in the future the Indians are requesting that a school be built on the Reserve. The Chief and Band have consented to allow the Mission to have a strip of land on their Reserve for a Mission and a school house. Mr. Neddrie the school teacher here is a very competent and careful teacher and some of his scholars are very clever. Mr. Neddrie suggests that his holidays should be in August and part of September, as at this time of the year he has more spare time to look after the garden and school repairs and other work connected with his Mission and school. Sir,

I regret to have to inform the Department that owing to Mr Brisley (teacher of Oxford House) insolence and refusal to leave my home when requested to do so, I had to forcibly eject him.

I would not trouble the Department with this matter were it not for the fact that Mr Brisley will do so.

The facts are these. During the winter Mr Brisley wrote a very insulting letter to me, not satisfied with this he wrote to Inspector Dunn with a view of injuring my position as Agent.

About 9 pm on July 1st Mr Brisley called at my home and demanded in a most insolent manner, "that I sign his quarterly school returns at once." I quietly asked him to call at the office on Monday morning and he could have the returns duly signed. This occurred in the presence of some friends we were entertaining in my home.

Later in the evening Mr Brisley returned and again demanded that I sign the returns at once. I repeated what I had told him before, and asked him to leave the house, this he refused to do, so I proceeded to make him, he resisted and received some damage as a result.

If the Department will refer to Mr J.T. Blackford Chief Fire Ranger, Norway House. He will verify what I have said as he was a guest in my home at the time.

I have the honour to be

Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Mr Lazenby,

In response to your request, I am writing a short account of our Exhibition which was held on December 15, at Oxford House Day School.

This year the pupils were twenty in number. As soon as the first snow fell in October, our thoughts turned to the Exhibition, and it was the wish of the children, as well as of the teacher, that it should be bigger and better than at any previous time. There were eight girls ranging in age from six to seventeen years. Three of these had never attended school before.

The yarn was taken to the school, and from a selection of fancy patterns, the older girls made their choice, and knitted one pair of short socks, and very fine warm gloves. With extra sweater yarn, provided by the teacher, very dainty sweaters were made by the older girls. They were taught to follow directions from a book of knitting instructions. The beginners had larger wooden needles made for them by the Indian Chief. They made nice warm scarves, with a fringe of contrasting colour. They also knit warm sweaters, with elbow length sleeves, in a plain garter stitch.

As soon as the knitting was completed, two Saturdays were spent at the Mission, washing, rubbing, and boiling the colour out of ordinary flour bags. Each girl chose her own pattern from Eaton's catalogue, and work was begun. Binding of various colours, fancy pockets, and embroidery enhanced the beauty of the older girls' aprons. The younger ones made use of crayons; a picture, a warm iron; and embroidery cotton for outline stitch. They were then carefully laundered, and put away for the Great Day.

Immediately dresses were begun. Again Eaton's catalogue was brought to school, and many recesses were spent, with the big heads and little heads looking over the dress section. Patterns were chosen, and from one basic pattern the girls made the necessary alterations. The teacher gave no assistance in this matter to the older girls as this was their fourth year at dress-making, and they now make all their own clothes in the latest fashion.

The beginners cut their own dresses, and were shown how to baste (Elephant steps), and then the other stitching, (Fairy steps), necessary for sewing. To help them keep their seams straight, a faint line was drawn with a pencil.

Needle cases followed, made from old felt hats. The leaves of the cases were cut from small pieces of flannelette. During this time, the older girls were busy at home during the evenings. Two rag mats had been ordered. One order had come from Winnipeg. The girls dyed the required rags at the Mission, and received Six Dollars for the finished mats. These were also available for the Exhibition, as they had learned hooking in school.

It was also decided to add a table with preserving and cooking. Both Blueberries and Raspberries had been preserved in the fall - thirty jars, to be exact. These are dated, and at the wish of the girls, left at the Mission until wanted.
The older girls have made Christmas fruit cakes for the past two years. These were iced, and exhibited. Also exhibited in this department were loaves of white bread, and apple pies. This work was done at night, and on Saturdays, at the Mission. One girl was so afraid that the teacher would knead her loaf bread, that she appeared at the Mission in the darkness of early morning, without having had her breakfast at home. Needless to say, with such interest, the bread was very light, and beautifully baked.

All this time too, the little boys were struggling valiantly with biscuit boxes, saved since August. Nails were carefully removed, and stored in a bottle for future use. The boys were also divided into two groups. The experienced ones showed a great improvement over last year. Their wood working vocabulary had increased, and they were familiar with the tools provided. Articles of a more useful nature were made; three-armed towel racks; fancy tie racks; match scratchers; match boxes for a table or radio; little wagons with elephants or ducks on them; rocking horses; very lovely tea-pot stands sand-papered and varnished (and subsequently wrapped and put on the Christmas Tree for the Mothers); door stops of various kinds, and one nice table. Great exasperation was expressed, because the biscuit boxes were at least an inch smaller, and much thinner than last year.

All the articles mentioned above were either painted, enamelled, or varnished. Brushes were cared for, and thoroughly washed and dried. Paints were mixed to produce different colours and the teacher had daubs of paint here and there all over her clothes. Nevertheless, it was a wonderful time for the children. Many a recess passed with everybody sand-papering, or sawing, or using the drill. They sang as they worked, the many little English songs they have learned.

Everything was completed by December 14. As the teacher was busy with lessons, the two oldest girls were given permission to arrange the articles on tables and on the walls. They went around on tip-toe. Gave a final ironing to the dresses, put them on hangers, and arranged them beautifully. All articles had to be numbered. Booklets were prepared for the judges' use. Pencils were sharpened and placed inside the booklets. The following morning the prizes were tabulated, and arranged on the table.

Just before two o'clock, the children washed and combed their hair. All was in readiness at two thirty, and the parents, traders, and Minister arrived on time.

An opportunity was afforded the parents to view the work. The judges were called, and examined the exhibits. Before the prizes were presented, the children sang two songs. One of the Councillors presented the prizes; he had hurried home from a long journey just to be at the exhibition. Many speeches followed. One father said "We do not know how to teach our children how to do these wonderful things. No one else has ever done this for us. We are glad that you have come among us, and we are grateful to you."

So many believe that the Indian is hopeless, and yet when you hear them say "We are grateful to you", it makes you want to help them the more, and never give up until their dear little children have learned that with their hands to aid them, there is nothing too hard for them to do.

Signed:- Ada M Scoates.

Dear Sirs;

Last July my wife and I took over the work of Missionary and Teacher, I as the former and she as the latter, here on the reserve at Oxford House. During the past six months we have been trying to get our bearings while at the same time carrying our work to the best of our ability. More and more, however, we have come to feel our need for certain things (description of which appears below) and we were wondering if you could help us in any way. I might say that our feeling of need has become more acute and our determination to write you more resolute since we received and read some material on Indian work issued by the United States Office of Indian Affairs. Among this material were pamphlets such as Educational Service for Indians, Indians Yesterday and Today, their weekly field letter Indian Education and others with which I expect you are familiar. Among other things this material convinced us of the tremendous possibilities in the type of work in which we are engaged; but, as I have already said, it also accentuated the needs we have come to feel in our work.

It seems to us that before any plans can be laid which will be worthwhile pushing and reasonably assured of success in the realm of education for better living, certain things are required which we have not got. In brief they are:

1. A knowledge of the native culture. While a great deal of this must be picked up by living in that culture, nevertheless a great deal of time and misunderstanding could be saved if material assembled by experts on the subject could be studied while the living was going on—material like the Sherman Pamphlets just being published in the States. To date we both feel that we really know very little about the culture background, past or present, of the people among whom we are working; that is our first need.

2. A knowledge of the exact status of the Indian in this country. Although we have a vague idea of what "Treaty Indian" means our knowledge of what exactly an Indian can or cannot do morally, economically or any other way is negligible. I'd imagine a copy of the Indian Act would help us in this connection; but anyway the above constitutes our second great need.

3. Knowledge of the aims, objectives, and practical policies of the Government regarding the Indian. What exactly is the Indian Department trying to do for or with the Indians under its care? What policies does it advocate to those in direct contact with the Indian in order that those aims might be achieved? These are probably known to the Indian Agents but in a setup such as the one in this agency where the ones in direct contact with the people are the teachers and missionaries simply because the agency is so big, it seems advisable that they be known to the latter also so that the agent's work might be eased and greater all-round effectiveness result. This then is our third need.

4. A knowledge of what projects have been undertaken elsewhere but under similar circumstances for the improvement of the lot of the Indian. For example:
   What type of houses have been found to be best suited to Indian use from the standpoints of finances, health, etc.?
What work in Indian Crafts is being done and with what success?
What work in fish, game and forestry conservation has been tried? What values have been thus achieved?
What agricultural programs have been executed UNDER CLIMATIC CONDITIONS LIKE OURS?
What health education programs have been found to be effective?

These then are other things with which we feel we ought to be acquainted.

Now then, gentlemen, can you help us satisfy the above needs? Have you any publications with which you can supply us or can you tell us where such can be obtained? We would appreciate any Help you may be able to favor us with and eagerly await your reply to this somewhat lengthy epistle.

Yours truly

Dear Mr. Harvey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you seek information in respect to the cultural background of the Indians amongst whom you are labouring, the status of the Indian in this country and the policy of the Department in respect to the progress and general wellbeing of the Indian population.

I regret to state that the information in respect to these matters in print here is somewhat limited, and I should add that in view of the acute paper shortage that has now developed and the limited funds at our disposal, it is not at all likely that additional pamphlets will be printed at any time in the immediate future. It is my hope, however, that the information I am sending forward will meet your needs for the time being at least.

In respect to the cultural background of the Canadian Indian, there is a book on this subject, written by Desmond Jenness, Dominion Anthropologist. This is a very bulky and very costly volume, and I hesitate to recommend it unless you are prepared to spend a great deal of time in an exhaustive study of Indian anthropology, Indian folklore, etc. There is a magazine published monthly by the United States Department of Indian Affairs at Washington, entitled "Indians at Work", that might prove interesting to you and to your wife and helpful in your work.

The Canadian Indian is a ward of the Government and his exact status is outlined in the Indian Act, a copy of which I am sending forward. The reports of this branch for the last two or three years will give you a fair idea of governmental policy. This policy in the main in an economic sense has consisted of the organization of fur development projects, the conservation of fur life and direct assistance to Indians engaged in agriculture by the establishment of a revolving fund, from which funds can be secured by the Indian for the purchase of farm equipment, live stock, etc. A Handicraft Section was organized 4 years ago. We are at this date marketing handicraft products through a central warehouse at Ottawa. The turnover last year amounted to approximately $25,000. Actual organization work so far has been confined to Indian reserves in eastern Canada.

A health program was organized also about 4 years ago. This health program has as its immediate objective the arresting of the ravages of tuberculosis among Indians and the ultim

Reverend I. J Harvey,
United Church Mission,
Oxford House,
Manitoba.
ate eradication of this disease. In recent years T.B. sanatoriums have been established at Coqualeetza, B.C.; Cut'Appelle, Sask.; Dynevor, Man.; Fisher River, Man.; and Manitowaning, Ont. We have a medical division in the Department with two doctors in charge. In respect to health education in the schools, we have been following somewhat closely the textbooks and general health program promoted by the provincial departments of Education.

It may be stated in a general sense that the aim of the Government is to gradually bring the Indian up to a standard of living and accomplishment somewhat comparable to that enjoyed by the average citizen of Canada in a well organized community. In the East, where this has been to some extent achieved, the result is at least partial assimilation.

It cannot be said that we have yet succeeded in establishing what one might describe as an ideal housing unit for the Indian families. Climatic conditions in the country differ widely. For example, a house suitable at Aklavit might be wholly unsuitable in southern British Columbia. Where logs are available the log house appears to be the most satisfactory from the standpoint of comfort and fire hazard. In a number of localities in Ontario Indians appear to favour small frame houses, roofed with asbestos shingles and finished with a fireproof, artificial, imitation brick.

A number of worthwhile re-afforestation projects have been undertaken in recent years; hundreds of thousands of trees have been planted at the Six Nations, Muncey, Tyendinaga and a number of other reserves.

We are at this date encouraging Indians to go in extensively for what we usually describe as subsistence gardens. We are doing this in an attempt to provide the Indian with a better balanced diet and to keep down to the lowest possible figure our annual relief costs. You will be interested to learn that Dr. Orford, the Indian Agent in charge of the James Bay Agency, confronted with conditions somewhat similar to the conditions existing at Oxford House, succeeded last year in growing sufficient potatoes for a large number of his Indians and this spring informs us that he has sufficient potatoes in a well constructed root-house to provide seed to a number of bands.

Should you require additional information, I want you to feel free to communicate with us again.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Back either in December 1941 or January 1942 you were kind enough to send me at the United Church House at Oxford House, Manitoba, a copy of the Indian Act plus considerable other material concerning Indians. You also sent me a two or three-page letter outlining the policy and aims of the Indian Department which the latter is attempting to follow out in its work with the natives.

I appreciated that material very much and when I left Oxford to finish my College course, kept it for my successor in the hopes that it would be equally valuable to him. Now that I have finished College, however, I have decided to go back into Indian work.
this time at Cross Lake, and wish that I had kept the material you so kindly sent me.

I want to have as clear an idea as possible about what exactly the Indian Department is trying to accomplish and how it is going about its work, so that instead of working at cross purposes with you, the mission can cooperate to the full, thus increasing the possibilities of success.

Dear Mr. Harvey:

In response to the request contained in your letter of May 1, I am sending forward herewith certain information which I trust will prove helpful to you in your work at Cross Lake. It is unnecessary to state that, should you require additional information, you should feel free to communicate with us again at any time.

In looking over the material, I notice that there are very few references to the educational policy of the Department, and it occurred to me that you might like to have an expression of opinion on educational policy from me as you begin your new duties. Just at the moment we are finding it exceedingly difficult to secure the number of fully qualified teachers necessary to operate our schools. This condition is likely to continue for a decade at least and there is not much that we can do about it. However, I have arrived at a definite conclusion that Indian day school teachers, particularly in the outlying districts, should be members of the permanent Civil Service and that they should be employed for the full 12 month period, subject, of course, to the statutory holidays. They should qualify for superannuation and be paid a salary that would attract a large number of ambitious young men to take up this work. In other words, I have in mind the appointment, not of school teachers as such, but rather welfare and training officers. These men, working under the nominal direction of the Indian agent, should be responsible for instruction in the classroom, the distribution of relief supplies, the care of the dispensary, promotion of gardening and in fact everything relating to Indian welfare. I am convinced that

Dear Mr Lazenby,

Due to the fact that there is no official inspection of the Indian Day School during teaching days, I beg leave to make this report of my observations gleaned from the visits paid by myself.

The teacher has primarily laid a heavy stress on Health and Citizenship from the beginning of the school term and now enjoys the results with a fair measure of success. Her rigid enforcement of obeying rules of cleanliness, without exception to time, place or person is seen by the desks, walls, and windows, which are scrubbed every week. The school grounds are free from sticks or stones or shrubs which may cause physical injury. However, there is a lack of playground equipment and Tag games are the only ones enjoyed. The absence of unfair fighting such as ganging up on the man who's down, is the result of vigilance on the part of the teacher, and punishment when caught in the act.

English has improved somewhat, and I believe it is the result of doing away with interpretation and getting the child to do as commanded in the English language. There is no Cree used on the school grounds, and beginners learn English from the games they play. Other academic subjects were taught as in any Manitoba public school, and children attending more than 175 days completed one average year's work. However, the very beginners will spend more than one year in the first grade. During the next year there will be several students in grade seven but the teacher will be limited due to the lack of textbooks for that grade.

Industrial Art was taught in school by the teacher, employing one hour a week. On achievement day the girls displayed six dresses, four aprons, eight slips, pillow cases, towels, pot holders, and numerous small articles. During the course, they were taught the care of clothes as well as washing, ironing and patching. The boys had their toys on display and other wooden articles as could be made from packing boxes and nails.

At the beginning of the term, the school was painted, on the inside, and mudded on the outside. Window panes were replaced where necessary and the floor was oiled to keep down the dust. New seats arrived in October and were immediately properly installed. Eight other seats which had been given to an Indian to repair were salvaged from under the snow and made serviceable in my workshop. A sanitary washing fountain was installed to spread the hygienic activities, to minimize the communicability of disease. Old swing poles were removed to avoid injury, but the toilets which are both hazardous and insanitary cannot be improved until the Medical Officer makes his suggestion at Treaty time. Mrs Dueck supervised the boys in the making of shutters from biscuit boxes in order to prevent window breaking during the period when school is closed.

Mrs Dueck and I appreciate your co-operation in conducting the activities of the Oxford House School, especially in that you have gone to the trouble of arranging the teaching term from August to May. We realize how much annoyance and extra burden is laid upon you whenever a new missionary wishes to materialize his ideas, and his successor does the direct opposite. We are looking forward to treaty time just as much as anxious as the natives. There are many problems that I am sure could be solved when viewed at close range by Dr Corrigan and yourself. I hope that I will be able to arrange a motor boat to take the treaty party to the school.

I remain, Sincerely

Sgd Wm H Dueck

I beg to advise that I have today received a letter from Mrs Olga Dueck, written from 285 Edison Avenue, Winnipeg, stating that due to personal reasons she has been forced to leave Oxford House and return to Winnipeg.

REPORT OF TOUR OF NORWAY HOUSE AGENCY BY AIR JANUARY 7th TO JANUARY 13th, 1946.

Took off for Narrows at 1030 hrs, arrived Narrows 1100 hrs. Nearly went through thin ice in front of U.C. Mission, just missed open water by few feet.

Interviewed Rev. Kehler and Mr Clarke, Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company. Quite a number of women with children staying in the locality so their children can attend school. This would not be possible without the Family Allowance. I inspected the school, Miss Helen Loewen is the teacher. She is 23 years of age with a grade 9 standing. There were 14 pupils present. The building is the most dilapidated school building I have ever seen. I would like to describe it. It is an abandoned Mission House built on semi-muskeg; the classroom is 10'x 28', the walls lean in and out, the ceiling sags and the floor heaves. There are large windows on a Southern exposure. There are no blinds and the children cannot escape the constant glare of the sun. It is almost impossible to see the cloth blackboard at the far end of this 'tunnel'. The walls are 8 ft. high, none of the doors open or close properly owing to the heaving of the building. The desks are of rough lumber and rickety. The teacher's desk is a packing case, and she has an apple box for a seat. At the far end of the room there is a large stone fireplace which provides ventilation, making it the only Day School in the Agency where the air is not foul. Taking all this into consideration, I consider that Miss Loewen is doing valiantly. I gave her what advice and encouragement I could. Took off for Oxford House 1600 hrs, arrived 1645 hrs. It was almost dark.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 9th re the Day Schools at Oxford House. There are 2 schools in operation at Oxford House; the old one referred to as No. 1 is being taught by Mr George Donald Loewen, and the new one No. 2 which is the renovated Council House is being taught by Miss Elsie Brandt. Both Miss B and Mr Loewen called in my office on their way to Oxford this fall. I gave them documentation papers and emphatic instructions that they were to be completed and forwarded to you and that the expeditious payment of their salaries depended on the completion of this procedure. I am at a loss to know why Mr Loewen has not carried out those instructions. However I will send him the papers enclosed in your letter of the 9th ultimo with a repetition of my previous instructions.

You state that you have received no communication from me with regard to this school. On Oct 11th I forwarded to you the quarterly returns for the month ending Sept 30 for both these schools and in the column for remarks in each return was stated the date of opening and other particulars of interest.

Mr Phelan complains in a letter about the spate of Day School requisitions which have been going in from this Agency. I would like to point out that 6 new day schools came into operation in this Agency this fall and the sending of these requisitions was unavoidable and very necessary and I could not anticipate their opening last April. However I am circularizing all the day schools under my jurisdiction to submit requisitions to cover the school year 1947-1948 and to have them in my office not later than the 1st of February and I will forward same to you before the break-up. If I waited for the date quoted by Mr Phelan which is April 30, they would be caught by the break-up and could not reach your office until the middle of June at the earliest.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, February 27, 1947.

Dear Mr. Bateman:

I have received and carefully read your reports on school inspections at Oxford House and Split Lake. I hope to be writing to you in the near future concerning the new schools we intend building in your inspectorate this year.

By now the school supplies ordered for Oxford House should have reached there. We arranged for the books to reach Ilford by January first. The Northern Transportation Company was requested to handle them by tractor train from there. The Basic Readers of the Curriculum Foundation Series were being supplied to these schools. Thirty-six desks were ordered from Moyer's in Winnipeg and our records show that these were delivered to Inspector Hamilton in Winnipeg on January 4 and that they too were shipped to Ilford for onward routing by tractor train. It is unfortunate that all these supplies have not yet arrived to alleviate conditions at these schools.

We are writing to Dr. Dorsey of the United Church concerning Mr. Loosen and to Bishop Lofthouse about Reverend Mr. Cosley. You will be receiving notification in the near future of the new teachers' salary scales which we intend taking into effect on the first of September, 1947, and which it is hoped will attract a better class of teacher into our day schools.

I appreciate your frankness in submitting these reports and feel that they will do much to bring about a needed improvement in the education of the Indians of your inspectorate.

B. Scott Bateman, Esq.,
Inspector of schools,
The Pas, Manitoba.

God's Lake Indian Day School,

Requesting authority for the provision of one-room Indian Day Schools on the Oxford House Indian Reserve, in the Norway House Agency; and on the Chisasibi Indian Reserve, in The Pas Indian Agency, both in the Province of Manitoba, and for which funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to complete the erection of one-room Indian Day Schools on the Oxford House Indian Reserve, in the Norway House Indian Agency, and on the Chassawin Indian Reserve, in The Pas Indian Agency, both in the Province of Manitoba;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Oxford House Reserve and on the Chassawin Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

THAT the building materials for these schools have already been purchased and have been shipped by tractor trains to the sites of both schools;

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of both these Indian reserves, there are few builders or contractors in the area, nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT, as the result of enquiries made by our field officials, we have been able to obtain the following labour tenders for the erection of these buildings:

| Contractor                        | Oxford House | Chassawin |
|----------------------------------|--------------|-----------|
| Matthews Construction Company, The Pas | $5,900.00    | $5,900.00 |
| Elmer Sabiston, Winnipeg          | $6,000.00    | -         |
| Emery Brothers, Flin Flon         | $6,800.00    | $6,400.00 |

THAT the lowest tenderer, namely the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, has building crews
in this region and is known to be a satisfactory and reliable contractor. This tender covers all transportation and boarding costs and is felt to be fair and reasonable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the erection of the Oxford House Indian Day School by the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand nine hundred dollars ($5,900.00) and of the Chassonain Indian Day School by the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand nine hundred dollars ($5,900.00), this being the most suitable arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children on these reserves in time for school opening in September.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your telegram of Oct. 3rd, following please find information requested.

No. 1. Attendance Indian Children York Factory School.

Ten children are attending at the present time. This attendance will probably rise to Twenty in the near future, as families are expected to move in from Fort Nelson.

No. 2. Progress Construction New Schools in Agency.

Oxford House School, No. 1 has been completed, with the exception of installation of Selkirk Chimney.

God's Lake United Church School is also completed, with exception of Selkirk Chimney.

When these chimneys arrive it will be only a matter of hours to install each one.

I made a final check on God's Lake United Church School on Oct. 17th.

This building has been completed sufficiently to legalize payment to the Contractor.

However the finishing was an extremely hurried job and reflects no credit to the man concerned.

The living quarters especially are very poorly painted and finished, the cupboard doors do not fit and the paint has just been slapped on.

In the Main Glass Room, the small windows on the North side are fitted with Butt hinges, these hinges were not countersunk; when the windows are closed it leaves an eighth of an inch gap.

The Contractor was told about all this by the Assistant Agent at God's Lake and agreed to rectify it, however it was not done as apparently the main idea was to get finished and get back to town.

Unfortunately, the Contractor had left when I made my final inspection. The whole finish shows a definite lack of interest. In my opinion this man should not be given any further Contracts with the Indian Department.

Attached please find Final Progress Report.
No. 3 Joint Recommendation by Mr. Grafton and myself on New Schools Next Year.

There are no further reserves in this Agency that would warrant a joint school, due to the lack of Non-Treaty children.

No. 4 Report on New Teachers.

To date I have only met Miss M. Rahn of God's Lake United Church School, she appears to be doing well and seems to be quite efficient.

I see no signs of teachers for Oxford House schools, No. 1 & 2, nor for Split Lake.

Could I be advised as to when these teachers may arrive?

I would like to draw your attention to the Quarterly Return ending Sept. 30th, 1949, submitted by this Agency. Under the heading "Schools & Education", reference is made to a Permanent School at Shoantown.

I would appreciate your comment on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Superintendent,

Further to my Army Message, we are prepared to accept Mrs. Atkinson for the Oxford House school but I wonder whether it is practical to have her go in at this late stage of the year, especially when the missionary has been filling in. Dear Dr. Dorey:

I have for reply your letter of December 9 concerning Mrs. George Atkinson. When Mr. Davis wrote to me he said as follows:-

"It is probable that Mrs. Atkinson could fill our vacancy at Oxford House School where we have a small school and teacherage."

I replied indicating my doubt as to whether it would be practical to have her go in at this late stage of the year and suggesting that she might do very well in one of the other schools.

I have not received a reply to my last letter as yet. At the present time, Mrs. Mabel Gosbee is teaching in the Oxford House No. 2 School, and I believe your missionary is carrying on in the Number 1 School.

I have the honor to enclose herewith the Quarterly Return for the Oxford House Day School for the Quarter ended Dec. 31st.

It will be noted that the epidemic of measles reduced the attendance somewhat. However, although there were during Sept. and October, some 100 cases of measles on Oxford Reserve, there were no deaths from measles. During October there were three deaths of children, two of which were pneumonia, which may have been developed from the measles.

I have a report from the Dispenser at Oxford House, written January 5th, in which he states that he does not think there is one sick person in the Oxford House Band.

Sir;-

I have the honor to enclose the Report of the Oxford House Day School for the Quarter ended December 31st.

There was no school during the September Quarter, as there was no building to be had. The old church had been pulled down, and a new one in course of erection at the same time as the new school was being built.

School opened Oct. 21st, and I notice that classes were held for 50 days, which I consider very full time.

The teacher states, in connection with the new building,—"We are enjoying a fine, warm school building now." I have not seen the new building, but if built according to my instructions, which I understand it was, it should be comfortable and satisfactory.

Ottawa, August 15, 1934.

Sir:

The authorities of the United Church of Canada have nominated Mr. Geo. H. Harris to succeed Mrs. R. L. Bacon as teacher of the Oxford House Indian Day School for the academic year 1934-35.

Mr. Harris holds a first class professional Manitoba certificate and has had several years' teaching experience. In addition, he is a graduate of the Manitoba Agricultural College. He will be allowed salary at the rate of $95 a teaching month.

Please give him every possible assistance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Wm. Gordon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

See Memo to Treasury Branch on #3 of City Eddy School Min.
Ottawa, June 20, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada, under whose auspices the Indian Day School on the Oxford House reserve is conducted, have arranged the transfer of the present teacher, Mr. George H. Harris to perform the duties of farm instructor and manual training teacher at the Norway House Indian Residential School. As successor to Mr. Harris, the church authorities have nominated the services of Mrs. Ada Murray Scoates, B. Sc. Mrs. Scoates is a graduate of Mt. Allison University, has had five years' teaching experience and holds a first class permanent teaching certificate. Her husband, Rev. D. J. Scoates, B.A., B.D., has been appointed missionary on the reserve.

The Department is approving of the appointment of Mrs. Scoates as teacher for the coming school year, to begin duties on September third, next, the date the school re-opens after the summer holidays. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $95.00 per teaching month.

I would request that you give Mrs. Scoates every possible assistance in her work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

P. G. Lazenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

December 17th 1910

The Secretary Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I am glad to avail myself of this opportunity to write to you, and trust you will take my request in this letter. Last spring when Mr. W. Lemieux was here making peace parleys, I asked him if the government would build us a school at Oxford House, and he promised to call your attention to this fact. Since then we have not heard anything more, and we are now anxious to know if you will build us a schoolhouse, and send us a teacher. We are at present using the church for school purposes, and we doubt that this is a good thing.

We also asked Mr. Lemieux about a doctor—a great number of our people are sick, and we have many deaths, and a number of lives could be saved if we had a doctor here. Our nearest doctor is at Norwood House a distance of nearly 200 miles away. If we had a doctor who made his home here at Oxford, he could easily attend to the needs of our people as also the God Lake Band, as well as Slave Lake, both of which are within reasonable distance.

We also asked Mr. Lemieux if the government would supply us with some cattle, as they have done to the other Reserve. That is some of the Coco River and Bull River also. We would like to know what your disposition is in the matter.

EXTRACT from March Quarter Return received from Fred W. Stevens, Esq., Teacher of the OXFORD HOUSE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL, on File 123-6-2.

For 19½ days during this quarter school was closed because of there being no wood. The only reasons anyone seems to have to offer are (a) There were no men to bring wood (b) The Chief is no good. Now, as it is only about two hours work to bring a load here, any of the men could have brought wood, for there always were one or two around. As to the chief, if the people didn't intend to bring wood, the chief could not have made them anyway. As it is, the chief's position is made very burdensome for these people believe that "He who is greatest among you shall serve you". The only people around here who are living up to their promises are the old ones. Attendance is very low because of the time when school was closed. While school was in session, attendance was good.
Ottawa, July 4th, 1931.

Sir,

On the March quarter return of the Oxford House Indian Day School which has recently reached the Department, it is noted that the school was closed for 19 days during the quarter owing to lack of wood. The teacher further states that the reason for this was that the chief did not arrange with any one to supply the wood required.

If you have an opportunity, the Department considers that it would be advisable to point out to the chief the necessity for having wood supplied to the Oxford House School ahead of time so that there may be no occasion for closing the school for the same reason as it was found necessary to close it during the March quarter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie

Dear Sir:

We have a letter from Rev. Leonard Bacon, B.A. of Oxford House, whose wife is the teacher at the Day School there. This letter deals with the question of supplying some provisions which would be necessary in order to provide the school children with a hot meal at noon. When I was at Norway House this summer this matter was discussed and it was discovered that in a number of the schools this arrangement had been in operation for some years. Our workers feel that Oxford House is just as needy in this regard as schools on other missions and I would urge upon the Department the wisdom of making it possible for Mr. and Mrs. Bacon to care for the children in this way. They have proved themselves to be self-sacrificing workers during the past year and I am sure their usefulness would be greatly enhanced if the Department makes this plan possible. It is suggested that a grant be made of:

40 pounds of cocoa,
100 pounds of sugar,
300 pounds of beans,
200 pounds of rice,
and a few cups, plates and spoons.

Your favorable consideration to this request will be very highly appreciated by,

Yours faithfully,

Arthur Barnes

Ottawa, August 26, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6242, file 530-5, part 1)
Sir:

I beg to refer to Mr. R.A. Hoey's letter No. 123-6-5 of the 19th September, 1940, with which was returned my voucher No. 564, for more definite details on the invoice.

The invoice was returned to the Hudson's Bay Company at Oxford House, (where there is no regular mail service), and later on was received back again. However, it was not correct, and had to be sent back again with more explicit instructions as to what was required. I have now received the invoice again, with the details, and stating the days on which the men worked. As to the rate per day, I may say that there was no rate of pay set for the men, but they were offered the goods stated on the invoice, for doing the work of re-roofing the school building.

I therefore beg to re-submit the voucher, with the amended invoice attached.

Your obedient servant,

Attention Mr. P. Phelan

Re: Oxford House U.C. Indian Day School

I have to hand your letter of March 29th 1946, wherein you request my comments regarding statements made by the teacher Miss Loewen. I sent in a report of a tour of this Agency dated 15 January 1945 under file 21-A which states in part as follows:

"The school building should be condemned. It is of logs, the ceiling is only 7' from the floor and there is no ventilation. This girl 'Miss Evelyn Loewen' has to walk nearly 3 miles to and from school each day and the weather was around 40 degrees below zero. The Attendance is good."

With regard to Miss Loewen's statement, it is quite correct. She has far more children attending than she can cope with under existing conditions. The building is 20' x 30' with a 7' ceiling and there is absolutely no provision other than the doors and windows for ventilation and with the present overcrowding, it is ideal for the propagation of tuberculosis. It is the opinion of the writer, that as a school building, it should be condemned. There is no teacherage and the teacher who boards at the Mission House, has to walk 3 miles to and from school over rough and exposed country in all kinds of weather. There are enough children of school age on this reservation to warrant the building of 2 day schools and 2 teacherages.

The last time I was in Oxford House, which was March 9th and 10th, the school was so overcrowded that I instructed Miss Loewen to divide all the children of grade 3 and under into 2 groups and alternate them in half day periods.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 17, 1946.

Mr. E. B. Goodman, Indian Agent,
Norway House, Manitoba,

I have your letter of the 16th ultimo, with reference to the Oxford House School.

It is evident from your letter that a new school is required, but owing to conditions over which we have no control it is not possible for us to provide a new building this year. Is there any building on this reserve that could be rented, temporarily? If so, we would be prepared to pay rent for it and would even spend a reasonable amount of money to put it in a habitable condition. We would be prepared also to provide the salary for a second teacher.

When preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1947-48, attention will be directed to the necessity for new schools on this reserve.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa

Attn: Mr Bernard F Neary
Re: Oxford House Day Schools

In reply to a letter received from Mr Phelan d/17 May 46 in which he suggests that I locate a building at Oxford House that could be used temporarily as a day school and he further states that the Department would be prepared to pay rent and would even be prepared to spend a reasonable amount of money to put it in habitable condition and further that the Department is prepared to provide the salary of a second teacher.

While having treaty at Oxford House I made investigation. The Indians of that band are prepared to lend us their council house for a year to be used as a day school. This building would require a certain amount of work before it could be used for such purpose, 40 pieces of Beaverboard or Plywood 4' x 8' estimated cost $50.00, 3' x 12' of rough lumber $30.00 per ft., 25 lbs 2" nails, 15 lbs 4" nails, 10 lbs 1" chingle nails, 1 window - 6 light 10' x 12', size of glass 2' x 3' 1/2" estimated cost $2.50, Labor $60.00. The cost of freight from Norway House at $5.00 per cwt would be approximately $95.00.

The rough lumber I can provide from the Norway House Mill, the other material will have to be purchased from outside and if this expenditure is approved, in order to save time it would be appreciated if the other materials were purchased through Inspector Hamilton's office, Winnipeg. The beaverboard would have to be cut into 2' x 4' sections and tied in bundles so that it could be stowed in canoes and carried over portages.

There is an oak table and a chair in this building which would do for the teacher, a blackboard could be borrowed temporarily from the existing day school. 30 single desks would be required, 10 large, 10 medium, and 10 small. This building is the same size as the present day school at Oxford House. I have a capable man to look after the work of conditioning this building. This second school is urgently needed on this reservation and if this project is approved I would like to know as soon as possible as there is not much time to get it in condition by Sept 1st.

E.B. Goodman,

On the 17th May 1946 I received a letter signed by Mr Phelan in which he requested me, when preparing the estimates for this Agency for the fiscal year 1947-8, to draw the attention of the Branch to the necessity for new schools on this reserve.

They have 1 old log school here which is entirely unsuitable and antiquated and the 2nd school this year is being conducted in the patched up Council House. It is requested that 2 new schools and 2 teachers residence be built this year, or that the building of them should commence this year. Owing to the geographical location of Oxford House, it will be impossible to do anything until next winter and all the building material necessary could be shipped in by tractor and building could commence the spring of 1948.

Any buildings erected on the inland reservations would have to cover a period of 2 years for the reasons above mentioned.

For the health and well being of the children of this reservation, it is absolutely essential that the new schools be erected as soon as possible, and it is requested that this matter receive your serious consideration.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.
Extract from Inspector B. Scott Bateman's Report, dated February 11th, 1947, regarding Oxford House Day School #1. Original on file 1-1-6

File: 123-6-5

The condition of the building is very poor. The building is old, built of logs, and lined with V-joint. The lining is warped, buckled and shrunk, and the loss of heat through the walls and ceiling must be very great. The building was cold, and most of the younger students were blowing on their hands in an effort to warm them. Snow on rubbers under the stove had not melted by recess. Outside wraps were all worn in school.

I understand that the fires are started in the morning by a child from a neighboring home and frequently the fire is not lighted until 15 minutes before school is called. It is therefore impossible for the school to be warmed up until after dinner.

The caretaking is done by the teacher. It is not well done. The school is not attractively decorated. There is little attempt on the part of the teacher to make it attractive. In spite of the teacher's best efforts, it would not be possible to create inspirational surroundings in such a building.

Mr. E.B. Goodman, Indian Agent,
NORWAY HOUSE, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 11th inst., with reference to the Oxford House Indian Day School. We also received report recently from Inspector Bateman in which he remarks on the bad condition of the present school.

In preparing our appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48, we were confronted with a very large number of requests from all parts of Canada for new schools. We could only provide for some of them this year and as far as your Agency is concerned, the following amounts are provided in the 1947-48 appropriation.

Jack River C.E. Teacher's Residence $3,500.
Cross Lake U.C. School and Teacher's Residence combined $8,000.
Island Lake R.C. School and Teacher's Residence combined $8,000.

In other words, there is an amount of $19,500. provided for new school buildings in your Agency during the coming fiscal year.

Owing to the information supplied in the second and third paragraphs of your letter, we would like to know if the conditions at Oxford House apply also to Cross Lake and Island Lake. If so, it might be possible to purchase material for Cross Lake, Island Lake and Oxford House from the $16,000. available. I presume it will be easier to erect the teacher's residence at Jack River.
We will be pleased to hear further from you offering any suggestions you consider necessary.

In the first part of this letter we referred to report from Inspector Bateman. One of his statements was that the fire in the school is started in the morning by a child from a neighboring home and frequently the fire is not lighted until fifteen minutes before school is called. As a result, it is impossible to heat the school before noon.

The Department feels that this condition, at least, could be remedied and we are prepared to allow a reasonable amount for the balance of this winter for someone who will light the fire much earlier in the morning so that the building may at least be warm when the children arrive at school.
