Mr. F. M. Hughes,
In charge, Indian Agency,
Norway House, Manitoba.

Oxford House Indian Day School.

You will recall our recent conversation in Winnipeg with regard to the day school construction program in your agency for the 1949-50 fiscal year. The program falls into three main phases:

(a) The construction of a day school or day schools at Oxford House.

(b) The construction of a teacherage at the Island Lake R.C. School.

(c) The moving of a building from the God's Lake Mine to God's Lake Narrows to replace the old school at present in use there.

You will receive separate letters concerning projects (b) and (c). I am anxious to settle in the near future as to whether we will build the usual type of day school at Oxford House or whether we will erect prefabricated buildings.

I understand the following situation exists at Oxford House:

There are two schools in operation at present:

(1) Oxford House No. 1. This is in the old building situated near the nursing station. I am informed that the nursing station has been built with extra accommodation for the teacher of this school. This would

(copy sent to Mr. Davis)
mean that a school without a teacherage would be required to replace the old building presently used. Unfortunately, we have no bill of materials prepared for a standard one-room school without a teacherage. Because of other more urgent work being done by our Architects and Engineers, it is most unlikely that we will be able to prepare such a bill of materials see some months to come. It may therefore be necessary to consider the purchase of a prefabricated building (without a teacherage) at this point.

(2) Oxford House No. 2 Indian Day School. This school is being conducted in the renovated council house. My information is that it is some distance from the first school but I have no details. Unfortunately, Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds have never completed the annual day school teacher's report as required (see March 1948 issue of the Indian School Bulletin). As a result, our information on the situation at Oxford House is very poor.

It would seem that a standard one-room school with attached teacher's quarters would be required at this point. This school would be identical to that being constructed now at Island Lake, for the United Church Mission area. We do have a bill of materials for such a building and we could arrange to ship in these materials during the coming winter. However, in view of the fact that we may have to order a prefabricated building for Oxford House No. 1, you may want to consider the provision of a prefabricated building also at Oxford House No. 2. These buildings would differ in that Oxford House No. 1 would have no attached teacher's residence.

Finally, there is the possibility that a two-room school would serve this area better than two 1-room schools. Unfortunately, we have no exact details as to the distances involved and therefore it will be necessary for you to make a recommendation concerning this.

We will anticipate a reply from you covering the points raised above.

Bernard F. Neary,
SUPT. OF INDIAN EDUCATION.
Norway House, Dec 14/48.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter 123-6-1 (E) of Oct 27/48 with reference to building program for new schools this coming year.

Oxford House I.R. as you know is being taken, or is already taken out of this Agency but I will give any information I can that might be of help to the Department and the new Supt at Ilford.

In my opinion two separate schools should be built at Oxford otherwise many of the pupils would have too far to walk. Your information re No. 1 school is correct excepting that I doubt very much if we can depend on getting accommodation for the Teacher at the Nursing Station. If Mr & Mrs Reynolds intend staying at Oxford for another year or two then no residence need be built at No.1 school as Mr Reynolds teaches there and his wife teaches No.2 and they both live in the United Church residence. During Mr Neary's visit to Winnipeg the question of material being manufactured at Island Lake sawmill for these schools was mentioned. This cannot be done for a 1949 building program as the lumber would have to be made during 1949 and freighted to Oxford & Island during the winter of 1949-50. If, as stated, these buildings are to be provided in 1949 then possibly prefabricated building would be better.

With reference to a building to be moved from God's Lake mine to God's Narrows, I reported nothing suitable but Mr Davis states that there is one near the lake which I possibly missed or thought was Occupied. It might be well to have the Supt from Ilford look over these buildings and make his recommendations.

Yours truly,

F. M. Hughes,

God's Lake Narrows Indian Day School.

Reference your 207-4B of November 15

Immediately your letter was received here, we began to prepare an outline design for a one-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence which could be erected at a lower cost than the present building.

This building will not have a full basement and will be heated by stoves and not by a furnace. It should, therefore, be much easier to erect and will serve our needs in the more northerly areas, where it is often difficult to put in a full foundation.

I have been advised by our Chief Architect that he expects the first set of these plans to be ready about the middle of January. I hope that I will have a chance to show them to you during your visit here. A bill of materials is also being prepared so that we can order the necessary building supplies for both God's Lake Narrows and for Oxford House. In the meantime, we would appreciate full shipping instructions for the supplies to be forwarded to Mr. Bennett at God's Lake.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

Photo No. 1, looking west (9 A.M.) shows the east side of the original (No.1) school, and the front door of the recently built nursing station. The lake is just to the right, down a high bank.

A two-room central school is not the present answer. School accommodation is requested in the No.2 area and should be built in the area (or not far therupon) indicated in red in photo #3.

In view of the fact that the above two schools are now located in your Superintendency, please be advised that we are requesting the Departmental Purchasing Agent to buy the necessary materials for the erection of low cost one-room Indian day schools and attached teacher's quarters for each of these reserves.

the Oxford House No. 2 School only this year (that is the school at present operated in the old council house).

If the above instructions are not clear in any way, please do not hesitate to write for further details.

I am also attaching a copy of the standard bill of materials for this school so that you will know what has been ordered, and also a blueprint of the building which we intend to erect.

Enc.

Bernard F. Neary,

PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL.

Requesting authority to accept the tender from the North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited for the materials required to construct the following schools at a cost of $11,670. f.o.b. Winnipeg, Manitoba.

(1) God's Lake Narrows, Norway House Agency, Winnipeg, Manitoba.
(2) Oxford House, Norway House Agency, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Three extra copies of the Order in Council are required by Indian Affairs Branch.
February 4, 1949.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT funds are provided in the 1948-49 appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to purchase materials for the erection of the following one-room Indian Day Schools and teacher's residences on the Indian Reserves shown below in the Norway House Agency, Province of Manitoba:

(1) God's Lake Narrows
(2) Oxford House

THAT these materials require to be shipped in now to the sites of the schools by tractor train so that erection can be carried out next summer;

THAT these schools will be erected by local Indian day labour under the supervision of a foreman carpenter;

THAT every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for the materials required for the buildings;

THAT only two firms have submitted complete tenders for all materials required:

(1) Monarch Lumber Company Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, have quoted $14,236.57 f.o.b., Ilford, Manitoba.

(2) North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, have quoted $11,670. f.o.b., Winnipeg, Manitoba.

THAT the officials concerned consider that the price quoted by the North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited to be the lower of these two in spite of the varying f.o.b. points of origin;

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Lumber and Supply Company Limited to supply the materials necessary for the erection of these two schools and on which they have quoted a price of $11,670. f.o.b., Winnipeg, as it is necessary for the materials to be purchased now in order that the erection of the building of these schools can be carried out this summer.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Minister of Mines and Resources.

I was very happy to get your letter re-
the new school and teacherage to be built here
next summer.

I am submitting to you for your approval
an alternative plan, placing the school and
teacherage just north of the council house; on what
is at present church property. I have spoken to
Dr. Best, our Superintendent of Home Missions
concerning this and he was in favor of the
use of this ground for this purpose.

Mr. Goodman may not at the time of
choosing the site have thought of using this
piece of property. The playground is ready and the
gardens can be easily expanded.

I am very much in favor of getting the school
and playground away from the homes of the Indians
as much as possible.

The present mission house and old warehouses
behind are being torn down and taken away this
year, so that the buildings are well separated but
not too far apart. Hoping that this will meet
with your approval; 2 remants -

Sincerely yours,

H.M. Reynolds.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

As you are aware, it is our intention to erect a new day school at Oxford House this summer. Materials have been ordered and we hope to have them sent to Oxford House by winter freight.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 6 JULY 1949

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 22nd June, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 estimates, Vote 230, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, to complete the erection of one-room Indian Day Schools on the God's Lake Indian Reserve and on the Oxford House Indian Reserve, both in the Nelson River Indian Superintendency in the Province of Manitoba;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the God's Lake Reserve and on the Oxford House Reserve;

That Section 56 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest......."

That the building materials for these schools have already been purchased and have been shipped by tractor trains to the sites of both schools;

That, due to the very isolated situation of both these Indian reserves, there are few builders or contractors in the area and outside contractors are not interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That, as the result of enquiries made by field officials of the Department of Mines and Resources the following labour tenders for the erection of these buildings have been obtained:

| Contractor                  | God's Lake | Oxford House |
|-----------------------------|------------|--------------|
| Elmer Sebastion, Winnipeg    | $5,000.00  | $5,000.00    |
| Matthews Construction Co.   |            |              |
| The Pas                     | $5,000.00  | $5,000.00    |
| Emery Brothers, Flin Flon    | $800.00    | $800.00      |

That the lowest tenderer, namely Elmer Sebastion, of Winnipeg, has produced evidence to the effect that he will build these schools in a satisfactory way. His tender covers all transportation and boarding costs and is felt to be fair and reasonable.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources
The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the erection of the God's Lake Indian Day School and the Oxford House Indian Day School by Mr. Elmer Sabiston, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for each project, this being the most suitable arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children on these reserves in time for school opening in September.

Clerk of the Privy Council

Re: Oxford House Indian Day School

I recently inspected the above mentioned school, which is under construction, and found it practically completed. However, Mr. Sabiston had only put on two coats of paint and I advised him to put on a third coat and do some more work on the cupboards in the kitchen. The workmanship of this building seems to be fairly good and I consider it should be completed by now and Mr. Sabiston will be moved to God's Lake.

The bricks that were purchased from the North American Lumber Company and shipped in, were found not fit to put in the chimney as they are of a very poor quality and most of them are crumbling. I advised Mr. Sabiston to leave the chimney shaft so we can install Selkirk Metal Chimneys.

I am taking this matter up with the North American Lumber Company, requesting them to ship in these chimneys free of charge, and I will advise you later as to my success in this connection.

Attention - Bernard F. Henry, Esq., Supt. of Educ.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your telegram of Oct. 3rd, following please find information requested.

No. 1. Attendance Indian Children York Factory School.

Ten children are attending at the present time. This attendance will probably rise to Twenty in the near future, as families are expected to move in from Port Nelson.

No. 2. Progress Construction New Schools in Agency.

Oxford House School, No. 1 has been completed, with the exception of installation of Selkirk Chimney.

God's Lake United Church School is also completed, with exception of Selkirk Chimney.

When these chimneys arrive it will be only a matter of hours to install each one.

I made a final check on God's Lake United Church School on Oct. 17th.

This building has been completed sufficiently to legalize payment to the Contractor.

However the finishing was an extremely hurried job and reflects no credit to the man concerned.

The living quarters especially are very poorly painted and finished, the cupboard doors do not fit and the paint has just been slapped on.

In the Main Class Room, the small windows on the North side are fitted with butt hinges, these hinges were not countersunk; when the windows are closed it leaves an eighth of an inch gap.

The Contractor was told about all this by the Assistant Agent at God's Lake and agreed to rectify it, however it was not done as apparently the main idea was to get finished and get back to town.

Unfortunately, the Contractor had left when I made my final inspection. The whole finish shows a definite lack of interest. In my opinion this man should not be given any further Contracts with the Indian Department.

Attached please find Final Progress Report.
No. 3 Joint Recommendation by Mr. Grafton and myself on New Schools Next Year.

There are no further Reserves in this Agency that would warrant a joint School, due to the lack of Non-Treaty Children.

No. 4 Report on New Teachers.

To date I have only met Miss M. Rain of God's Lake United Church School, she appears to be doing well and seems to be quite efficient.

I see no signs of Teachers for Oxford House Schools, No. 1 & 2, nor for Split Lake.

Could I be advised as to when these Teachers may arrive?

I would like to draw your attention to the quarterly Return ending Sept. 30th, 1949, submitted by this Agency. Under the heading "Schools & Education", reference is made to a Permanent School at Shantown.

I would appreciate your comment on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. H. Staunton,
Superintendent,
Nelson River Agency.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of above date, enclosing Pas' School returns for September quarter, and requesting information regarding Mr. McIntosh, etc.

In reply would say that I was under the impression that Mr. Agent Courtney had reported on this matter to you some time ago, on my arrival at the Pas' last summer, Mr. Courtney informed me what he had done about teachers for the school, and I then verbally instructed him to report to you on the subject.

Regarding Mr. McIntosh, he is a teacher that was sent down to the Pas' to take charge of the Public School for the North West Government; he came down the river with Mr. Courtney, arriving at the Pas' on, or about, the 12th of July.

Immediately on Mr. Courtney's arrival home he discharged Mr. Lamb, the old teacher, for reasons that are already known to you, and arranged with Mr. McIntosh to take temporary charge of the Indian School pending the engaging of a new teacher.

Subsequently he arranged with Miss Hines to teach, and to my knowledge she started on the 12th of August.

I take it that the days given in the returns are correct; I instructed Mr. Courtney to have each teacher make out a return for the service rendered; this he has done overlooking the matter of dates, and not signing the returns of Mr. McIntosh.

I hereto attach a calculation showing the amount that each teacher is entitled to; I also enclose the returns.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant

Sir:

I have the honor to make the following report in answer to your letter of the 24th June last, relative to certain teachers appointed temporarily in the Pas Agency. Viz:

George Crane, Red Earth Reserve; an Indian of John Smith's Reserve. Age 27. Married. Trained in an Indian Day School. Very imperfect in English. Never taught before. A very crude specimen. Mr Hines should be censured for sending out a man like this. Would recommend that he be retained until the thirty of June next as he cannot very well get out before that time on account of family. Travelling, from the first of November till the Middle of May is a great hardship in the Pas Agency.

Albert Smith, Big Eddy School. Treaty Indian of John Smith's reserve. Age 27, married, trained at Emmanuel College. Very uncouth. A slightly better specimen than Geo. Crane. I make the same recommendation as in the former case.

Isaiah Badger, Moose Lake reserve. Treaty Indian of John Smith's Reserve. Single. Educated at Battleford Industrial School. This is a much better than the other two, and may do fairly well. He had only been teaching a few days so I could not judge much of his work. Would recommend that he be retained for the present.

Frank Baker, Chemawawin Reserve. An Englishman single, age 31 years. Promises well: think he will soon tire of his job. Very enthusiastic at present. Would recommend that his services be retained for the
the present.

I hope shortly to make a general report on school matters in this Agency.

I have the Honor to be,

Sir

Archdeacon MacKay usually made the nominations; but during his absence they were made by Rev. Mr. Hines. Sir,

At the band meeting held last summer on the Pas Reserve, and on various occasions since, the Indians have brought up the question of a Day School on the reserve just across from the Town. I mentioned the matter to the resident Anglican Clergyman Mr. Fraser, and he agreed to try and find a house which could be rented for the purposes of a school, but no suitable building could be found, and there the matter rests. The school Trustees of this Town are now completing a new school for the junior classes, on the English Church Mission property, close to the river and just across from the reserve. I have made an arrangement with them to take into this school, say 16 of our Indian children at a charge of $2.00 a month for each child, and subject to the endorsement of the Dept. of Indian Affairs. I have not mentioned this as yet to the band, and will not do so till I receive a reply to this communication.

There is a halfbreed settlement here and there will be quite a number of Non Treaty Indian children going to this school, that belong to these people. It may be necessary to help a few of our Indian children in the way of stockings and mitts, and perhaps caps, and I would recommend that a sum of say $50.00 be placed at the disposal of the Agent here for that purpose if required.

There are about 70 children on this reserve of school age and no school in operation, and the prospects of getting a teacher for the Big Eddy school for the winter are not bright, as there is no place there where a white teacher can get board.

Yours truly,

J.D. McLean, Esq.
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,

Sir,

At the same meeting mentioned in my letter No. 362/113 it was resolved by Chief Constant, seconded by Norman Lathlin, Councillor, and carried by all the male members of the band, a large majority of whom were present, to petition the Department to build a day school on the reserve, immediately opposite the town of The Pas.

Discussing the matter among themselves at their meeting, the various speakers pointed out that the Department had promised to build a day school for the education of their children, when they moved from the south side of the river. Further notwithstanding a Boarding School is to be built at the Eddy, a day school will be needed, as all their children cannot be admitted, as other reserves will also send children to this Boarding School. Their younger children will need to be taught at a day school near home, while the elder ones will be admitted into the Boarding School. They further protested against permitting their children to attend the white school at The Pas. They were not approached in the matter when the arrangement was made, and it is strongly against their wishes.

In this respect I would strongly recommend that a day school be built for these people. The present arrangements of the Indian children attending the Pas Public School is looked upon with disfavor by the Indians. Personally I am not in favor of the arrangement.
There is always a certain clash among the two classes. The white children look down upon the Indian children, and being very sensitive by nature the Indian children do not like to attend the white school. It would therefore be to the interest of the Indians to have a day school on their reserve. The missionary in charge of the Protestant mission here says they stand ready to supply a teacher for the school. In the meantime I think a building could be rented for the purpose of holding day school, until a school house could be built.

Your obedient servant.

Indian Agent.

Referring to Department letter No. 117558/1 dated July 16th in connection with a school for the Pas Band opposite the Pas town, I would say that I have obtained a house which will be suitable for temporary quarters. The house is now in process of repairs, and by the time I get authority from Ottawa, it will be ready for school purposes. The rent will be $60.00. The building is built of logs. 16 x 16, with a ceiling 8 ft. high. The building will be well fixed, for winter, so that it will be warm and comfortable. The material and furnishings of the old school are all available.

The teacher had in view by the Church of England is an elderly English lady, and although not holding a certificate, has a good general education, and is qualified to teach an Indian School. I am personally acquainted with the lady, and I am sure she would make good.

I would further urge the Department to erect a building on this reserve for school purposes. It is absolutely necessary. The boarding school now building will not house all the children of school age here, as many others will be admitted from other reserves. It is therefore essential that a day school be built on the Pas reserve, at the point opposite the town of The Pas, as this point would be central; and children from Carrot River settlement could also attend.

I hope therefore that the Department will take immediate steps to build a Day School as the build-
ing temporarily used will not be suitable for any length of time. Regarding the school, I am expressing the desires of the Indians.

Your obedient servant.

Indian Agent.

Referring to the latter part of Department letter No. 117558/1 dated August 25th, 1913, regarding the Pas School, in which it was intimated that "the matter of erecting a new school will, however, be kept in mind for next year's estimates."

In estimates for 1914-1915 I estimated for $1600.00 for a new school building. This was the estimate which was "kept in mind."

The town of The Pas has three school buildings which they are selling, as they are erecting a large brick school. These smaller buildings are available for purchase now, and will be vacated in February. I have made enquiries, and the secretary was authorized by the Chairman of the Board of Trustees to offer me one building for $800.00. I may say two of them are sold. The one remaining is a new building used about a year, and built of fir. It is a bargain at $800.00 and should be bought for the Pas Reserve. We could not erect a building for $800.00. I would strongly advise the purchase of this building. I think the daily attendance of this reserve would justify the purchase, as the building used is wholly inadequate for school purposes.

This building is 36x24 ft. Mr. Wm. Armstrong will move it across the river for $150.00. This is an approximate figure. He says it may not cost so much.

Dear Sir:

Since the election of the new Chief, Patrick Constant and several councilors in December 1923, to form the new council for The Pas Indian Band many matters of vital importance to the future welfare of the Band have been taken up and discussed by them.

We know that the usual way of getting matters of outstanding importance before your department is through the local Indian agent. We are not going over his head at all in taking the matters we wish to discuss, up direct with you, as we have already talked them over with Mr. J. Waddy, who suggests that we write you personally in reference to the matter of day school education of the children on the reserve.

As we think your department must undoubtedly know, because your department is responsible for the condition that has obtained, there has been no day school in one section of the Pas Reserve for the past three or four years. In this district there are today, running around, idle and uneducated, some fifty-five children of school age, who are deprived of educational facilities in every way shape and form. There is not now, nor has there ever been a day school building in this section of the reserve. For the short time that a day school was conducted in this district some years ago an old tumble-down shack was rented and used for the purpose. It was entirely unsuitable and was torn down because it was useless for any purpose. This we would like to say, was before Mr. Waddy became the local Indian Agent, and was a matter which should have concerned and interested his predecessor, which apparently it did not very much. This however, is a matter of ancient history, and nothing can be gained by discussing that phase of the question any further.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6242, file 531-1, part 1)
The question for immediate consideration is the remedying of this deplorable, and we think inexcusable condition of affairs, which has been allowed to exist for so long in reference to the important matter of the primary education of the children on this section of the Pas reserve to which we have just referred.

A special meeting was called by the New Chief for Jan. 17th. to discuss this matter. It was felt by the Council that this condition could not be tolerated any longer, and upon the suggestion of the Chief, it was unanimously agreed that we should without delay write direct to the Indian Department to ask them to at once erect a suitable school building, centrally located to accommodate all the school children in the district. It was also decided to ask the department to erect an extra, and separate building for the purpose of the children having their noonday meal because of the long distance many of them would have to go to attend the day school.

There are very many arguments we could submit in favor of the granting of our most reasonable request, but we feel that your Department will at once realize the need for the school building we ask to have erected and they must know without our saying so that there is nothing more important to the people of the Pas Reserve, as also to all the people of the province as a whole than the matter of a secular education for the children. Our children, some fifty-five of them are today, on the Pas Indian reserve deprived absolutely of a chance to get an education. We want this state of affairs corrected as soon as possible and we most respectfully wish to draw the attention of your department to it, feeling sure that you will without delay take this matter up with us and the Indian agent, Mr. Waddy and that we will soon have the school we so much need.

We wish to thank you in anticipation of your immediate attention to this important matter, and we have the honor to be,

Your Humble Servants,

Chief

Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge the communication of the 21st instant, which was signed by yourself and several councillors of the Indian Band on The Pas Reserve. I have noted that you are urging the establishment of educational facilities and in reply I have to inform you that the Department has lately given your needs serious consideration. Bishop Lloyd of the Anglican Church and the Superintendent of Indian Education have recommended that a two-roomed school, with residence facilities for the teachers, be provided as soon as funds can be found for the purpose. There are many pressing claims on Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education and it is unlikely that public moneys can be secured for the building activity during this calendar year. Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of Jan. 29th, 24, in reply to our letter regarding Educational Facilities on The Ias Reserve, your file no. 128-7-1.

Your communication addressed to me has been discussed informally among the members of the Council and it becomes my duty to reply.

We note that Bishop Lloyd has been interested himself on our behalf, and has recommended that a two-room school with residence space for teachers be built. We are pleased to know this as it is in line with our request of recent date.

We note also what you say in regard to our trust fund of some $75,000.00. You say "School facilities could be provided as soon as the season commences this year, if the Council see fit to vote, say $7,500.00 for this purpose."

Speaking personally, I do not see that we are under any obligation to vote any money for the purpose you suggest in your letter, for the reason that by treaty made with many bands, of which the Ias Band is one, your department agreed to maintain schools for Indians on reserves, supply ammunition and twine annually to a stated amount, also implements and cattle, from the funds of the Department.

The fact that our having a private, or trust fund in the Bank to our credit does not enter into the question at all. That is a purely private or personal affair with the Band, and we are only a little more fortunate in being so situated than other bands, at which of course we are very much pleased.
We think that Your Department has been very negligent in the matter of providing educational facilities for the children on the Pas Reserve inasmuch as some 55 or more children have been denied an education altogether for four straight long years on our Reserve, just because there was no school building and no teacher provided by your Department as you were and are under a legal and a moral obligation to do.

We wish again to repeat our request that your department provide adequate school facilities for the children on the reserve, this summer without fail, and from the general funds of your Department, as we think you are obligated by treaty to do.

At your request we are taking this matter up with our Indian Agent, Mr. J.W. Waddy at once, and we trust there will be no difficulty or delay in this important matter.

I have the honor to be, Sirs,

Your Humble Servant.

We the undersigned Chiefs of the various Indian Reserves Tributary to The Pas, in convention assembled at Chief Patrick Constant's house on The Pas Reserve, during Christmas week 1924 hereby resolve as follows, in regard to the matter of public school education on the different Indian Reserves:

I - That a better qualified class of teachers be at once provided to teach our Indian children. This because many of the teachers are only lay-teachers and have no regular teacher's certificates to qualify them to teach in public schools. This situation applies to all reserves.

II - That in the matter of the much needed and many times asked for public school building and teacher to provide any education for some 50 or 60 children who have been deprived of all educational privileges for the past four years or more on the town end of The Pas Indian reserve, we very much deplore this condition of affairs, and ask the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, to at once remedy the situation as the regulations of the Department and the Indian treaties require day schools to be established where needed and a secular education provided for Indian children everywhere.

III - That the views expressed by certain Indian Agents to the effect that the day school in localities where boarding schools are in existence conducted under the management of religious or other bodies, are unnecessary and interfere with the efficiency of those institutions in the matter of attendance and so the day school might be dispensed with altogether, as for instance the case referred to in clause #2 above are entirely wrong, and any Indian agent advocating such a thing has not the interests of the Indians in his agency at heart.

IV - That a copy of this resolution be sent to the Indian Department with the urgent request that the questions referred to in clauses I and II be given their immediate consideration.

Sir:

During my recent visit to The Pas Agency it was rumoured that the Rev. Mr. Horsefield might obtain the appointment as teacher in The Pas Day School, to succeed Mr. Humberstone.

Mr. Horsefield taught at Grand Rapids, and I am informed his services were unsatisfactory. He also taught at the Big Eddy Day School and while there we had occasion to complain as Mr. Horsefield closed his school without permission in order to carry out his work as Missionary at outside points. The Pas Day School is an important school and in securing a change of teachers I was hopeful of obtaining the services of someone who would produce marked results.

It was also intimated that Mr. Horsefield did not care to reside in the Department house, but preferred to live in the Town of The Pas. I think the Department should insist that our house be occupied by the teacher in charge of the school.

My information in connection with this matter is only that gathered in conversation, but I thought it well for the Department to know, should Mr. Horsefield be nominated.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, July 21, 1933.

Right Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to Your Lordship's letter dated March 31st, last, regarding the nomination of a teacher for The Pas Indian Day School, to succeed Mr. John P. Humberstone, who was retired as from the 30th ultimo.

In this connection I have to say the Department is informed that the Rev. Mr. Horsefield, who formerly taught at Grand Rapids, might obtain the nomination as teacher of The Pas School. When Mr. Horsefield taught at Grand Rapids, his services were not entirely satisfactory. He taught also at the Big Eddy Day School, and, while there, complaints were received that he closed the school without permission in order to carry out his work as missionary at outside points.

The Pas Day School is an important school, and it is hoped that, in making a nomination, the services of a qualified teacher will be obtained, one who will be able to produce marked results at this point. It has been intimated, further, that, should Mr. Horsefield be appointed, he would not care to reside in the Department's house but prefers to live in the town of The Pas. It is considered that the teacher appointed should occupy the house provided.

I am drawing the above matters to Your Lordship's attention, in order that you can give due consideration when nominating the services of a teacher for The Pas Day School. I should be pleased if Your Lordship would forward a nomination, stating full particulars as to name, qualifications, experience, etc.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Right Rev. Wilfrid Thomas, D.D.,
Bishop of Brandon,
Brandon, Man.

Memorandum: Deputy Minister,

Mr. Inspector Harlatt in his report on the Manitowahon and Pas Agencies recommends the renting of five buildings erected for church purposes by the Church Missionary Society in the Pas Agency, at the rate of $40 per annum each. These buildings, it appears, are absolutely necessary for school purposes, as the old buildings are useless.

There are seven schools in this Agency, and the only building fit for occupation is the one at Big Billy. He also suggests the construction of a new school building at the Pas Reserve, at a cost of $1800. This building, according to Mr. Harlatt's idea, should be large enough for two teachers, one of which is provided for already at a salary of $300 a year. The old building in this case is of no further use. The $1800 will cover costs and building. As regards the salary for the other teacher, Mr. Harlatt thinks that the North West Government would be willing to provide a teacher, as a number of half-breed children resident on the reserve will attend the school. For the five buildings which it is proposed to rent the department will, of course, have to supply desks, etc., which can be done from the regular vote without anything being placed in the estimates.

Mr. Marlatt, in another report, of the 14th December, suggests the appointment of two Farming Instructors in the Portage la Prairie Agency, one to be stationed on the Roseau River Reserve and the other on Swan Lake Reserve. The person at Roseau River recommended by Mr. Marlatt is a half-breed resident on the reserve, and his services, Mr. Marlatt says, can be obtained for $200 per annum; and the other is a resident on the Swan Lake Reserve, and can be secured for $240 per annum. Mr. Marlatt considers that these farmers should be paid by an assessment on the products of the Indians of 10%, which would be funnelled here to an amount for the purpose. In this way it is thought that they would soon become more than self-supporting.

475 bushels of seed wheat will be required for the reserves in the Portage la Prairie Agency, for which no provision has been made in the estimates.

Mr. Marlatt, as you are aware, suggests that Mr. Martineau be transferred to Portage la Prairie and that he receive a salary of $1800 instead of $1000 as at present. The estimates already provide $200 for office rent; and as there would be no office rent at Portage la Prairie, there would be really no increase in this case.

As regards Mr. Reater, no provision was made in the estimates by the Commissioner and Mr. Marlatt is strongly of opinion that his services should be discontinued and the work of his agency done by Mr. Martineau.
Mr. MacLatt is very desirous that a primary Kindergarten outfit should be furnished each of the schools in his Assembly, and he thinks that this might be done at a cost of about $14 or $15 for each school, and he considers that the result would be much more satisfactory if this were done.

Sir,

With reference to new School Building at the Pas Reserve, Pas agency,
This building was completed some time ago according to plans and specifications and is a commodious and substantial building with two class rooms on the first floor and large store room above,
I regret to inform you that the cost is more than anticipated, at the time of my visit to the reserve I looked carefully into the accounts and found that the total cost is about $2100, as you are aware accounts have been paid and advances made to the amount of $1500. I instructed Mr Agent Courtney to issue vouchers for all outstanding accounts, the reason for the estimate being exceeded is largely accounted for by the cost of transportation of material from Prince Albert to the Pas. I had been very much misinformed in regard to it, the cost of the building should be credited with the sum of $200, for transportation of 100 school desks and other articles not pertaining to the building which will reduce the building to an actual cost of about $1900. I handed over the advance of $178.42 received in your letter of 22nd of June, No 137269 to Mr Agent Courtney with instructions to account to you direct of all expenditure made by him.

I trust that you will honor all proper vouchers made by Mr Courtney in connection with this building, had I been on the ground personally I would have stopped operations pending further instructions when the $1500 was exhausted but as Mr Courtney had no instructions to this effect he naturally completed the building.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Extract from Report of Inspector S. J. Jackson on the Pas Indian Day School, August 12, 1920. Original on 117558-6

This school is in a very poor condition at the present time owing to there having been no regular school for the year before the June quarter. The building is a poor one about 15 x 20 and in poor condition.

Robert Thomas was educated at a college in Prince Albert for 3 years and 3 years in Battleford Indian School with Principal Matheson. He has taught for 8 years and is 43 years of age. He was at the front in France for over 2 years and has acquired a taste for alcoholic liquors.

There are so many children on this reserve that the boarding school cannot accommodate them. A new school 20 x 36, 11 ft. ceiling should be built opposite the Pas town at an early date. I would recommend that Agent Waddy be asked to get a tender from Councillor Patrick Constant for a new school. It would be built of the lumber that is now being cut at their own mill and from their own logs and should have a stone foundation.

S. J. Jackson,
Ottawa, August 19, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Jackson, in a report to the Department on his recent inspection of The Pas Indian Day School, states that the building in which the school is conducted is in very poor condition. He states that there are so many children on this reserve that the boarding school cannot provide accommodation for them and recommends that a new school building 20 x 36 feet, 11 foot ceiling, be erected opposite the town of The Pas at an early date. He also recommends that Councillor Patrick Constant be asked for a tender for the erection of such a building and that it could be built of lumber that is now being cut at their own mill and from their own logs and that the building should have a stone foundation.

I shall be pleased if you will state your views concerning the erection of a new school building and forward an estimate of the cost of the same. Kindly give as full particulars as you can concerning the matter.

Your obedient servant,

For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
Sir,

I have the honour to tender as follows on the building 20x36 to be used as a school-house on the Pas Reserve:

Building to have a cement foundation, walls to be 12 feet clear inside, building to be shingle-roofed two coats of paint to be applied on the outside, two coats inside, two coats on the roof, six windows and one door, with porch. Building to be solidly constructed throughout and foundation to be well banked up. All material used in the building is included in my tender, as well as all labor used in the construction of the building. The price is also to include the construction of two small closets and all hardware in connection with erecting the building.

The Department may pay for any material I purchase for this building and deduct same from total amount of my tender.

For constructing this building complete, that is, per the above, I tender the price of $1469.00

Yours truly,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,— Re letter #117558/5 of the 19th August, in reference to constructing a school on the Pas Indian Reserve, near the town of The Pas, I have the honor to state that I have gone into this matter with Councillor Patrick Constant, of the Pas Reserve, and explained to him just what is desired.

I enclose a letter from him tendering on the contract I allowed for 12 foot walls, with an addition of two feet to the height by building the ceiling across the room two feet up from the top of the walls as we require all the air space possible.

I explained to Councillor Constant that the building is only under consideration, and that it may not be erected, and he understands this. At the same time it might be advisable to put it up immediately if for no other reason than that the cost of materials is still going up, and a school is urgently required at this point. Some material will have to be purchased as the Indians have only got rough lumber, and I have placed an item in the contract covering such purchases. I drew up a rough plan with a list of material required and helped Constant to figure out the cost, so he should not have any complaint later on. At the same time I did not overlook the interests of the Department. If the Department wishes the building to be constructed as per the tender I would like to be advised by wire, so as to get the cement in immediately.

MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Scott,-

Mr. Inspector Jackson recommended that a new day school building be erected at The Pas on a site opposite the town. The present building is rented from an Indian at $80.00 per annum. It is in very poor condition and too small for the purpose. The Inspector states that there are so many children on this reserve that the boarding school (Mackay) cannot accommodate them. He recommended that Agent Waddy be asked to get a tender from Councillor Patrick Constant for a new building, as he has a mill and can supply the lumber from his own logs.

The Agent now forwards a tender which he received from Patrick Constant, who offers to erect a building 20 by 36 feet and to supply all the material required and do the work at a price of $1469.00, and, if the Department purchases any of the material, the cost is to be deducted from the above amount.

There are 85 children of school age on The Pas Reserve, all of whom are Anglicans. Of this number 46 are in attendance at the Mackay Boarding School, which has its full enrolment, leaving a balance of 37 for whom day school accommodation has to be provided.

There is no doubt that a new day school is urgently required on this reserve and should be built in the near future. We are now paying $80.00 per annum rent, which represents a capital expenditure of nearly $1400.00 at 6%. The tender received is $1469.00 and for this amount the Department would have a building large enough to accommodate all the children who would attend and it would be better adapted and more central than the present rented building. It is probably too late in the season to have the work done this fall, but
but I would recommend that funds be provided in the next year's estimates and that this work be undertaken next spring. However, I shall be pleased to be informed as to what reply to make to Mr. Agent Waddy.

Ottawa, January 23, 1925.

Sir:

For some years, Church and Department representatives have urged the establishment of a day school on The Pas Reserve. Mr. Inspector S. J. Jackson, in 1920, recommended that a day school be built at an early date. Mr. Indian Agent Waddy, whose recommendation was sought, was quite in favour of such a programme. The Department wrote to you on November 10, 1920, asking for a recommendation.

The question was brought to your attention again under cover of August 8, 1922. Please note your file 205-14 A.

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan visited the Department in 1923 and urged the establishment of a two-roomed school and residence. The Department also received a petition from the members of the band. No funds were available, however, and the matter was not referred again to your office.

In October, last, the Bishop of Saskatchewan wrote in part as follows: "The conditions here (The Pas) have been a public scandal for some time. There are 55 children at this end of the reserve, from 7 years of age upwards, running wild. This school is urgently needed and should be proceeded with at once. The site should be central, near where we have built the Church of the Messiah, viz., the village end of the reserve."

When Mr. Indian Agent Waddy was sending in his estimates for the coming fiscal year, he wrote in part as follows: "The Pas Reserve is asking again for a day school near the reserve. My idea is slightly different from that of the church authorities and the Indians, who ask for a large two-roomed school. - - - - I would consider a small school sufficient at first, made so that it could be enlarged if successful."

In the light of these facts, I should be pleased if you would make a recommendation with reference to the provision of a combined day school and teacher's residence at The Pas. At the present writing, there is in the draft Estimates for Indian Education, 1925-26, an item of $4,200.00 in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:

I beg to report that the school and dwelling on the Pas Reserve, as authorised by Mr. Commissioner Graham, will be completed today.

I have advised Rural Dead Fraser here to try to get in communication with the authorities of the Church and have a teacher recommended to the Department.

Ottawa, August 18th, 1925.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, informing the Department that the school and teacher's dwelling on The Pas Reserve is completed, and requesting that desks and other equipment be supplied.

Relative to the 30 adjustable single desks asked for and the teacher's desk, arm chair and visitor's chair, I beg to say that we are requesting Mr. Commissioner Graham, Regina, to arrange for the purchase of this equipment. I may say that we do not supply adjustable desks owing to the cost. The desk we supply is known as the 'single school desk'.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of 1 wall clock, inexpensive, the window shades of the sizes required, complete with rollers, 2 brooms, 1 scrub brush, 2 mirrors, inexpensive, 1 dust pan, 2 metal combs, 2 galvanized pails and 2 enamel drinking cups. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

We are placing an order with the Government Stationery Office to forward to you a teacher's hand bell, double ink stand and 6 blackboard erasers. We do not furnish day schools with blackboard rulers and pointers.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Ottawa, August 18th, 1925.

Sir:

Mr. Agent Waddy informs the Department that the school building and teacher's dwelling on The Pas Reserve, which you were authorized to have built, is completed. He requests that 30 desks be supplied, also a teacher's desk and chair and a visitor's chair.

I have to request that you will be good enough to arrange for the purchase of this equipment. You should obtain prices from the firms mentioned in our letter No. 111-1-12 of the 13th instant. It is considered that the following sizes and number of each size of single desks would be satisfactory:

- 10 No. 5 - Pupils 7 to 9 years,
- 10 No. 4 - 10 to 12 years,
- 5 No. 3 - 12 to 14 years,
- 5 No. 2 - 15 to 18 years.

The teacher's desk should contain 3 drawers down one side and 1 drawer over knee space. The teacher's arm chair and the visitor's chair should match the desk.

After the purchase of these desks has been made, please forward certified vouchers in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
For Aast. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, informing the Department that The Pas Day School was opened on the 28th ultimo with 24 pupils in attendance, and stating that it will be necessary to have front seats to accommodate 6 more pupils.

In reply I beg to say that you should obtain from the E. N. Moyer Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, their price F.O.B. The Pas for the supplying of the 6 front seats of the sizes mentioned by you. You should obtain an account, in duplicate, and when the seats have been delivered, if in good condition, you should certify the account and send it to the Department for payment. If possible, there should be no overcrowding in the classroom, and if there is not sufficient room the children under seven years of age should not be admitted. It is hoped that there will be a regular attendance of the children of school age and that the teacher will meet with much success in the work. Please give the matter of the purchase of the front seats required your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

THE PAS DAY SCHOOL.

This school is in charge of Mr. J. P. Humberstone who holds his Second Class Professional and was appointed by the Church of England.

The roll called for 31 pupils and on the day of inspection, I found 22 present, 14 boys and 8 girls. The grades range from 1 to 3 and the children appeared well along in their studies. Mr. Humberstone has certainly succeeded in getting these children to talk and they can be heard clearly from any part of the room.

The school is of the improved type and I understand is quite comfortable during the winter.

The children were well dressed and clean.

Mr. Humberstone takes keen interest in his work and appears to be getting results.

The residence in connection with the school is a four roomed cottage with a very small basement. Mr. Humberstone pointed out that he had no place to use as a store room as the house only had four rooms with no back kitchen. The washing machine and tubs must either be in the kitchen or cut under the trees. An outside kitchen could be erected quite easily and at small cost. The present combined kitchen and dining room is not supplied with any cupboards. A work table should be built along one wall with cupboards above, which would greatly help Mrs. Humberstone in her house work.
You will note what the Inspector says regarding the lack of cupboard space in the residence at The Pas Day School. We might, with your authority, arrange to have the cupboards and table which the Inspector suggests built.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

THE PAS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Mr. J. P. Humberstone, who was in charge of this school when I last inspected it, resigned to take up other work, but I found him again in charge on this visit.

The school register calls for 31 children and 22 were present. The grades range as follows:

- Grade I - 13
- Grade II - 7
- Grade III - 6
- Grade IV - 5

These children spoke out quite freely when questioned, and I found their voices carried much better than those of the children at the Big Eddy School.

I do not consider the discipline good as the children speak out at any time and do not hesitate to get up and walk after anything they require. I checked this up.
THE PAS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

This up and instructed the Agent, on his monthly visits, to see that this condition was improved.

The school building was fairly tidy, but the windows were all closed and the air very depressive. I pointed out to Mr. Humberstone that these windows must be kept open, and instructed the Agent to have the outside windows put on with hinges so that plenty of fresh air may be obtained.

The school building and the teacher's residence are badly in need of painting and this work should be done, if possible, during the coming year.

I was not impressed with the appearance of Mr. Humberstone's residence, but he explained that the house having only 4 rooms and a small basement gave him no place to use as a storeroom and he was obliged to leave things out in the yard and on the verandah which otherwise might be stored away. A lean-to 12 ft. wide built on the rear of this house would provide for another bedroom and kitchen and could be made good use of by the present family.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 7, 1929.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, in a report on his recent inspection of the Pas Indian Day School, states that he did not consider the discipline good, as the children speak out at any time and do not hesitate to get up and walk after anything they require. He also states that he requested you to see, on your monthly visits, that this condition was improved. You should take this matter up with the teacher with a view to improving the discipline.

The Inspector states that he authorized you to have the outside windows put on with hinges, so that a supply of fresh air could be obtained. It is presumed that you have attended to this matter.

The Inspector further states that the school building and teacher's residence require painting next year. You should bring this matter to the attention of the Department early next Spring, stating the work you would advise be carried out and the approximate cost of same, also how you would propose having the labour carried out.

The Inspector recommends that a lean-to, 12 feet wide, should be built on the rear of the teacher's residence to provide a bedroom and kitchen, also storage facilities. I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter, stating whether you would recommend the erection of a lean-to, and, if so, the approximate cost of having the work completed.

I beg to enclose herewith a report
on the Pas Agency by Inspector Hamilton.

With reference to the Pas Indian Day
School, you will note the Inspector says that
the school building needs exterior painting and
that the teacher's residence is also in need of
painting outside. I may say that amounts have
been provided in the Estimates to meet these
expenditures.
THE PAS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The school is supervised by Mr. Humberstone, whom I found to be greatly interested in his work, and anxious to have the children make progress.

The roll calls for 28 pupils, 10 girls and 18 boys. The average attendance for last quarter showed 22.5, and up till the present in this quarter, 17.72. This school is well located and there is really no excuse why the attendance should not continue to be good.

The children were tidy in appearance, but some were poorly clad, and I noted a number with wet feet. The weather had turned very mild and as some were wearing moccasins without rubbers, this could not be avoided.

The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 11     |
| II    | 4      |
| III   | 5      |
| IV    | 4      |
| V     | 4      |

The work
THE PAS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The work examined was well done, but the children do not speak out well, and it is almost impossible to hear their voices across the room. I understand from Mr. Humberstone that when he is alone with the pupils, they speak out much better, and I have no doubt such may be the case as some of the children are very shy. Drill and singing is also taught, and I found the children did very well in this respect.

The school building needs exterior painting, and the walls inside are in need of kalsomining as they have become badly smoked. The teacher's residence is also in need of painting outside. This house is very small, having only two bedrooms, a living room and a kitchen. An addition across one end would allow for two more rooms, which are needed, as at present there are seven in the family, five children and Mr. & Mrs. Humberstone. The addition would make possible three bedrooms, a kitchen, dining room, and living room.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your 128-7-5 of the 19th instant, I beg to say that I have, as instructed, today visited The Pas Indian Day School and examined the pump and well. I find that the reason the pump-handle breaks, is that the well freezes at the bottom at the cylinder, so that it is useless to have the handle repaired at present.

I would suggest that it be left till spring, and that the well be properly covered in at the level of the ground, so that it will not freeze below.

The well is only about 24 ft. deep. A floor could be put in, say 4 ft. or so from the top of the crib, which would prevent the frost from going further down.

The pump is an old wooden one. Fixing the handle is a matter of a few minutes, to bore another hole for the eye-bolt which pulls out when the pump freezes.

However should you wish to have the well fixed at once I shall be pleased to have it done.

I presume the well is frozen to the bottom.

In regard to the wood-shed, I would suggest a building about 14x16-8 ft., walls of ship-lap and shingled, with a light cement foundation to keep the sills from rotting. I do not think a floor would be necessary. Such a shed could be built at a small cost, and if required I could submit a figure for the material and labor.

In regard to the wood supply, there is a good supply, all sawed up, at the present time. It is always a difficult matter to get the Indians to supply wood. They expect to be paid for it and I contend that they should at least supply school wood free. As you know they never want to have a supply of anything ahead.

I trust this will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, reporting on the condition of the pump at The Pas Indian Day School and also regarding the building of a woodshed.

With reference to the pump, it is considered that, as suggested by you, the carrying out of any repairs and placing the pump in good condition should remain over until weather conditions permit next spring. When considered timely by you in the spring, you may arrange to have the well properly covered in at the level of the ground, to prevent freezing. It is noted you suggest that a floor be put in about four feet from the top of the crib in order to prevent the frost from going further down. You may have this floor installed, and, if a new pump is required, you may arrange for its purchase and installation. The interior of the classroom is badly smoked
and should be redecorated. The exterior is very much

The pump house should be repaired at once. The

Ottawa, March 6th, 1934.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Hamilton's report regarding his visit to the Pas Indian Day School on January 29th, last.

Mr. Hamilton reports, in part, as follows:

"The pump house should be repaired at once. The lumber is off the rear of the building, leaving it open to the dogs and small stock roaming around the reserve. If this is not repaired, the water will become contaminated and, sooner or later, the pump will be broken. The well is for the use of the school and residence, and the pump house should be kept locked. The cost of these repairs should not exceed six or eight dollars.

"I noticed some of the seats were loose and a number of screws have disappeared. These should be renewed or before long the seats will fall apart. A good man could make all necessary repairs in four or five hours."

Provided the expenditure does not exceed the amount mentioned above, you may arrange to have Inspector Hamilton's recommendations carried out at once. Accounts should be submitted before the end of the current month in order that payment can be made from this year's appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Form No. 101
Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on the above school which I inspected on Tuesday, June 11th, 1935.

The teacher in charge here is Miss Anne Wright, who holds her 2nd Class Professional Certificate for Saskatchewan. There are 28 on the roll and the grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 14     |
| II    | 4      |
| III   | 3      |
| IV    | 4      |
| V     | 3      |

The children are fairly well along in their grades and are making progress. The epidemic of measles necessitated the closing of school for several weeks and this interfered greatly with the work. There is no comparison in the discipline and general management of this school now and when taken over by Miss Wright. It has improved even beyond expectations and much credit is due the teacher for her sincere and earnest work.

The children were well dressed and clean. Their hair was neatly combed and apparently free from vermin.

I noticed that all the seats were occupied and the school was clean and in a tidy condition.

The school building appears much neglected. A number of boards should be renewed on the outside wall, due largely to decay. All siding should be re-nailed and the exterior painted. The paint put on at the time of erection.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
THE PAS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

of erection has entirely disappeared and the building presents a weather beaten appearance.

The school residence outside is almost as bad as the school and should be painted. The interior is in fair condition. Miss Wright has taken excellent care of the furniture and it is almost as nice as when supplied two years ago.

I consider the school under excellent supervision and the children are making progress.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.
Ottawa, July 18, 1935.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, in a report on his recent inspection of the Pas Indian Day School, states that the school building appears much neglected. He states that a number of boards should be renewed on the outside walls due largely to decay. All siding should be renailed and the exterior painted.

I would request that you furnish an estimate of the cost of the repairs required to the school building; also an estimate of the cost of the exterior painting of both the school building and teacher's residence. When we have this information, consideration will be given as to whether funds can be allowed for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

S. Lovell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
The Pas, Man.,

July 29, 1935.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 128-7-5, dated the 18th instant, I beg to advise that it will cost about $30.00 to make the necessary repairs to the school buildings and $70.00 to paint the school building and the teacher's residence. I would be pleased to have authority to do this work right away so that it can be done during the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Samuel Lovell
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Sir:

Owing to lack of funds, the Department is not prepared at the present time to authorize the expenditure required for painting the exterior of the school and teacher's residence.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Dear Sir:

In reporting on a recent inspection of The Pas Day School Inspector Hamilton writes as follows:

"The school has been painted since my last visit and certainly presents a different appearance. The work was done with Indian labour and in every way appears satisfactory.

"The teacher's residence now looks worse than ever. This house should be painted on the outside as soon as possible, and the interior should be redecorated. It is many years since any expense has been incurred for decoration and the house is gloomy, dark and cheerless.

"The well pump is not working. I would suggest that a good pole fence be erected so as to keep stock away. The repairs to the pump and other work should not entail much expense, perhaps $10.00 or $15.00, and I would suggest this be carried out as soon as possible."

Please let me know the approximate cost of painting the teacher's residence.

I submit the following report on the schools in The Pas Agency, inspected during the Treaty Payment from June 1st until June 15th.

The Pas Day School:

Mr. Waller is in charge. He has taught in Indian schools for years and is greatly interested in his work.

The school building has been painted since my last visit, but should have another coat. The teacher's residence is in good condition. Mr. Waller has done some interior painting on his own and consequently the place is bright and cheerful.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON THE PAS INDIAN AGENCY

Educational

The buildings, both classrooms and teacher's residences, of the day schools, are for the most part, in poor condition, and hardly worth repairing. We put in the Estimates for 1945-46 for a number of new buildings to replace them, but the Department have informed me they cannot be allowed. They certainly should be built at the first possible opportunity.

It might help matters if more food was provided for a more substantial mid-day meal. I mean a quantity of dehydrated foods, such as peas, beans, lentiles, potatoes, etc., be provided, as well as the biscuits and some of the elder children taught to make a well cooked mid-day meal for the children. This would increase attendance, teach the children some domestic science and be beneficial to their health.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of February 2, regarding Dr. Yule's report, I beg to advise that the two rooms mentioned are store rooms, one for the girls, and one for the boys, for hanging their clothes, etcetera. These partitions could be taken out, but I do not think it would be a great advantage, as we would have to build porches on the outside of the school, which in all probability would have to have a separate heating unit.

I intend to include in my estimate for 1947-1948, an estimate for increasing the capacity of these schools without tearing out these partitions. I would suggest that an addition be built at the rear of these schools, which could be made a permanent structure.

As regards insulation in the ceiling, these schools have two coats of lath and plaster, and very few cracks, and I am not altogether in favor of having sawdust used for insulation in a school building, where there are a lot of children, as this sawdust would be bone dry, and would create a fire hazard. I think this situation could best be handled in other ways, even by the use of heavy building paper in between the joists upstairs.

Regarding doing any work at the present time, it would be practically impossible as we would have to close the school, and I respect their request that this matter be allowed to stand in abeyance until the summer holidays, and I will go into this matter thoroughly in my estimate next year, for 1947 to 1948.

Medical Supt., The Pas Agency, for January 1946.

Re: Norway House Trip

Our Provincial regulations call for 15 sq. ft. of floor space and 200 cubic ft. of air space per pupil. These figures were given me by Mr. Goodman at Norway House, who had obtained them directly from the Provincial Department. On my return I checked our schools on The Pas Reserve, which are identical in size and layout. These schools are 21 x 23 x 10 with an additional 7 x 21 x 10 porch, (this porch being under the main roof). The cubic space would thus allow 24 pupils, or, if the porch were included, 31 pupils. The square foot space would allow 32 pupils or, with porch included, 42 pupils. To comply with the regulations the ceiling should be 3 feet higher. In other words these buildings would require a 13 foot ceiling to bring the cubic air space in line with the square foot space. Even with these schools I think there is enough space between the ceiling and roof to fill these requirements. However, independent of this, by the removal of the partition and the installation of proper desks, conditions can be materially improved. These schools are cold and should be insulated and it should be done before the fall term opens this year. Of course, with the removal of the inside partition a porch would have to be added. These schools have a registration of 38 and 34 respectively.
Extract from Report of Robt. F. Yule, M.D.,
Medical Supt., The Pas Agency, dated October 1, 1946.

Dear Sir:

Pas Indian Day School,

I beg to advise in this connection that I am well aware that the schools are crowded, but not so much this year as last, owing to more children going to boarding school from this area, and there have been a considerable number whose parents have been enfranchised. But the situation as it stands at the present time is this:

The provincial government have a school in this vicinity which has not functioned for a number of years. The School Inspector for this area approached me with a scheme to build a big joint school in this area, to take care of half-breeds and Indians. I had his assurance that this was taken up with the Minister of Education for Manitoba, and through him, with our Department. If this scheme is successful, any work that I did on these schools would be simply a waste of money. I interviewed the Inspector a few days ago, and he assured me, "off the records", that there had been some agreement with the Department in Winnipeg and Ottawa, whereby one of our schools would be enlarged to take care of the half-breeds, and the Department of Education would see that the school at Moose Lake would be enlarged to take care of the Indians in that vicinity. Up to the present time, I have had no official word, but I have hesitated...
recommending any work on these schools, until I have been notified that the arrangements had been made, as I do not want to spend money without having a beneficial result.

I do not think that Dr. Yule knows anything about the arrangements or any discussions regarding this scheme. Consequently, he reported this in his monthly report. Labor is very scarce, and material is very hard to procure at the present time, but the cost to do these schools would be approximately $150.00 each, that is, to wash the kalsomine off, and paint. If, under the circumstances, the Department are willing to go ahead and re-decorate these schools, I will endeavor to have this done in the Christmas holidays.

Trusting that this is the information that you require, I am

Your obedient servant,

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

Shortages, The Pas School.

1. No fuel wood.
2. No biscuits.

4. Requisition for supplies not yet filled.
5. No bulletin #3.
6. No flag arrived in reply to my wire in June.

Thirty-four desks are crowded together leaving inadequate aisle space for the teacher or pupils. Enrollment is thirty-eight.

C.A.V. Clark

November 3, 1948.

Mr. E. Law,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
The Pas, Manitoba.

The Pas Indian Day School.

Mr. Moffat's report on Mr. Waller is quite satisfactory. In his General Comment, Mr. Moffat makes the following comments:

"I am glad to note that toilet paper, a basin, soap and paper towels have been placed in the school as requested in my report of last year. However, the school well has gone dry so that the benefits that should have resulted are largely lost due to lack of water. Mr. Waller secures his own water by hiring a car to bring it from the town. It is suggested that steps should be taken to deepen the well or if this is not feasible to take other means of assuring an adequate supply at the school.

The girl's toilet is in such poor repair that it is impossible to use it properly. As a result it is in a filthy condition. New and larger toilets should be built. I have suggested to Mr. Waller the advisability of checking the condition of the toilets regularly and of encouraging pupils to put them to proper use.

A number of students were sitting on boxes. Six new desks should be made available.

The plaster on the ceiling is broken in one or two places, especially near the chimney.

The removal of the partition at the back of the room has added considerably to classroom space. Even with this improvement, the room is quite crowded."
If enrolment increases it would seem advisable to consider the building of a new two-room school in the near future. When such a building program is undertaken, I would like to see space and equipment made available for teaching practical arts such as shop work for boys and home making for girls.

You are authorized to have another toilet constructed at a cost not to exceed $100. It is presumed that we will have a report from you with regard to the water situation.

You are aware, of course that when Major Clark visits The Pas that he is to investigate the possibility of erecting a two-room school next year. Would you please submit a requisition for the desks required stating the number of small, medium and large sizes wanted.

We are sending Mr. Waller four dozen large envelopes for use by the children in taking their report cards home.

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your letter of 3rd inst., files 531-1 (E), 531-5, 531-6, regarding The Pas Indian Day School.

The water situation at this school, was discussed with the teacher, Mr. Sam Waller, and he is not in favour of deepening the well. He prefers to use town water for drinking purposes and uses creek and snow water for cooking. Therefore, we request authority to purchase two ten gallon enamel pots with lids, and taps at bottom at $14.95 each. One for the teacherage, and one for the school. Mr. Waller says he will keep town water in these pots.

Regarding the plaster on the ceiling of the school, we would like to have this ceiling replastered, but do not know just what balance is left of our 1948-49 appropriation. Our 1948-49 estimates asked that $500.00 be set aside for repairs to this school. Please advise.

When Major Clark visits this Agency we will discuss the possibility of enlarging the school playground by approximately four acres, and also pick a site for the new school.

Your obedient servant,

E. Law,
