The PAS

A residential school was formerly operated by the Anglicans at The Pas. This burned in 1933 and the children were moved to the Elkhorn Residential School. It has now been necessary, due to the age of the building, to remove some of these children from the Elkhorn School and we are therefore faced with the need of providing dormitory facilities again for the Indian children scattered along the railway line between The Pas and Churchill. I would recommend that an Educational Survey Committee be established to visit this area and to report as follows:

(1) The educational facilities which should be provided for Indian children of the Anglican faith in the area.

(2) If the provision of day schools is recommended, where should these be situated and of what type?

(3) If a residential school is recommended, where should it be located and what pupil accommodation should be provided?

(4) Other specific facts and comments concerning the educational facilities presently provided and recommendations concerning co-operation with the Provincial Authorities.

I would recommend that this committee be composed of the following members:

(a) G.A.F. Clark, Educational Survey Officer, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

(b) Inspector of Schools nominated by Provincial Department of Education. (We have in mind either Mr. H.P. Moffat, Public School Inspector, The Pas, Manitoba, or Mr. Grafton.

(c) An Anglican Missionary, appointed by the M.S.C.C.

As funds are not provided in our appropriation this year for the construction of a school or a unit of a school at The Pas, I feel that this educational survey could be carried out in September, 1949.
Colonel Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary:

During the conversation that we had on your last visit to Brandon, I gathered that there is a proposal for the erection of a new school on the Devon Mission and I presume that this will be one with living quarters attached. I do not know, of course, whether the present school, of which Mr. Sam Waller is the Teacher, would still be in use, but if this is to be replaced, we would, as a Diocese, like to have the opportunity of considering the purchase of the residence and perhaps even gaining possession of the school building.

Our present residence for the Missionary is so situated that in the winter he is completely isolated and we find that with the visiting required at the Sanatorium and at The Pas Hospital, it is essential that he should live close to the highway and thus be able to use a car. For some time we have been considering the possibility of moving our house close to where Mr. Waller lives, but if you no longer would require this house as living quarters, it might be more economical to consider obtaining this instead of moving our present one.

While I realize, of course, that some time may elapse before a new school and living quarters are built, I felt it would be advisable to inform you concerning this matter so that if changes are made, our application may be on file.

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

Archdeacon of Brandon.
March 9, 1949.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION.

The Pas - Proposed Two Room School.

Mr. Waller is a bachelor of fifty-five years of age. He is a keen amateur anthropologist and nature lover and may not take kindly to sharing the teacherage with someone who does not share his enthusiasm. I can well imagine there are several teachers who would not like to live with a collection of pickled biological specimens. Besides, his status as a Welfare teacher probably involves his receiving visits in his quarters from the Indians and others.

I would remind you of the existence of another house close to the teacherage. This was formerly a nurse's residence and an attempt was made some time ago to obtain it for, I think, the Agency Interpreter. The Missionary, perhaps, might be regarded by Indian Health Services as an acceptable tenant.

Mr. Superintendent Law may now have worked out some ideas for town-planning on the Reserve and I would suggest that he be requested to furnish the Department with a large scale diagram such as we have obtained for the File Hills Reserve. On this diagram he may indicate his choice of a new school site. He may also send us any information he may be able to obtain concerning Mr. Waller's desire for the locale of his future service with the Department and also his reaction to the prospect of sharing the teacherage.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.
March 2, 1949.

Dear Archdeacon Norris:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 24th.

We hope to proceed with our building plans at The Pas either this year or next year. I cannot tell you at the present time whether it is our intention to close the old school entirely or to keep it functioning in addition to the new school which we plan.

However, I note that you are interested in the old building and will draw this situation to the attention of our Educational Survey Officer when he returns from James Bay next week. He visited The Pas recently and will be able to advise me further as to our need for the old building.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

531-1 (E), in connection with proposed two room Indian
Day School, The Pas, Man.

During Mr. R. S. Davis' visit to this Agency
last week I showed him the site which I thought most
suitable for the new school, and he agreed with me. He
stated that it is the Department's intention to build a
two roomed school with teachersage, manual training and
domestic science rooms, plan #891, with electricity and
running water, if possible. I am sending Mr. Davis the
address of Mr. G. A. Muir, the engineer in charge of
the Manitoba Government Telephone system work in this
district. They are taking electric wiring for their own
use across the river to their building on The Pas Reserve.
There is a possibility that we might hook on to their line
about 300 yards from our new school, which is circled on
the map I am forwarding to you. The electric line and
new school are marked in red.

If this location for the new school is approved
I would like to be advised as soon as possible so that I
may obtain authority from Mr. Davis to start digging for
water on this site. I have been unable to locate a well
digger in this district, so it may have to be done by hand.

Hoping this is the information you require.

Your obedient servant,

E. Law.

Replying to your letter of June 27th, file 531-5 (E), in connection with The Pas Indian Day School.

For the past six weeks, weather permitting, I have had men digging a well on the site chosen for The Pas school. It has been extremely difficult digging as the soil is very hard clay. There is no well digging equipment in The Pas, or vicinity. So far they are down about 40 Ft., and are just starting to get a small trickle of water. There is about two Ft. of water in the bottom of the well, but I want to be sure that we have sufficient water supply before finally deciding on the site. This is the reason I have not advised you before in this connection. I will wire you immediately, as soon as we have sufficient water supply.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from Superintendent Law of the Pas Agency, in connection with the above mentioned subject.

Mr. Law suggests building the school before water is located. However, I am not in agreement with him in this matter, as I feel we should have water before building. The Indians have wells on lower ground, which is about 300 yards or more from the school site. These are shallow wells and have plenty of water. Dear Sirs:

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary
Superintendent of Indian Education.

In connection with the digging of a well for the proposed two room day school on The Pas Reserve, your file 531-5 (E). I regret the delay in advising you further, but I have just returned from my holidays.

Up to the present time $600.00 has been spent on this project. We are down 75 Ft., through clay, with no change of soil. This is about 30 Ft. below river level. There is some seepage but I am not positive that there would be sufficient for the school. There is approximately 6 Ft. of water in the bottom of the well, but some of this would be rain water. There has been a cave in at the bottom, which I think is due to seepage, and in time will possibly increase the flow of water into the well, therefore I do not think we should go to the expense of digging another well at the present time, when I can not give any assurance that sufficient water would be obtained.

I would like very much to have the school built on this location as there is sufficient room for a playground, we would be able to obtain electricity, it is far enough from the highway to be safe for children playing near the school, and it is centrally located on the Reserve.

Would it be possible to proceed with the construction of the school at this location, under these circumstances. If this well does not have sufficient water another well can be dug about 50 yards from the proposed site of the school in lower ground, water from this well, if obtained, would of course have to be carried to the school.

Your obedient servant,

E. Law.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the Minutes of the Council of the Peguis Band of the 5th instant renewing the application for the establishment of a third school on their reserve I beg to say that a similar application was received in April of 1917.

Mr. Agent Carter was sent a blue print of the reserve and asked to mark thereon the location of the present schools and where the Indians wanted the new school built as well as the locations of the different Indian families on the reserve and the number of children of school age in each family. Mr. Carter furnished the required information, and he was informed that the Department was unable to erect a new school on the reserve then, as owing to the war, the funds at its disposal were limited, and he was told that so long as the war lasts they should arrange to transport their children to the two existing schools.

On referring to the blue print sent Mr. Carter I find that the Indians are located along the Fisher River, running for a distance of about fifteen miles through the reserve, which is twelve miles long. There is one school about two miles from the northern boundary of the reserve and the South Peguis School is about two and a half miles from the southern extremity of the reserve and the two schools are about twelve miles apart by the road.

It is the wish of the Indians to have a central school for the accommodation of about thirty children, all living within a mile and a half of the proposed site. There would
would still be enough children available for the other two schools, as there are about 135 children of school age on the reserve, and this would give about fifty children each for the north and south schools.

The Indians of this reserve are permanently settled on their locations and need a third school.

Sir,

Dear Sir:

I have visited the Indian Schools on Peguis and Fisher River Reserves and am now able to reply to yours of Jan. 9th.

The difficulty on Peguis Reserve comes from the fact that there are seven or eight white children whose parents are resident on this Reserve, and who have to be sent to Winnipeg or elsewhere to be educated. These children are quite young and their parents are experiencing much worry and concern owing to serious and costly illnesses having interrupted the course of their education. If the teachers on the Reserve were qualified there is no reason why these white children should not attend school on the Reserve for a few years until they are better fitted to leave home.

All the teachers on the Peguis Reserve are earnest, hardworking, and conscientious but not one of them is a qualified, certificated teacher. Two of them, viz., Mr. A.H. Tucker in charge of the South school and Mr. C.R. Harbord, in charge of the North school, have a real system of teaching which they are following with much success. The weakest teacher on this Reserve, measured by actual results, is Miss W.M. Stapleton in charge of the Central school. This is the school at which some of the white children might attend and the fact that it is the weakest one is the kernel and cause of the whole trouble. Miss Stapleton would do well in a Kindergarten or a school of Primary Grades. She seems to have no definite aim or system beyond the work of the first two or three grades and her work falls away from this point. I do not wish to be unkind but I must report conditions as I find them if my report is to be of any real value. I do not wish anything that I may say in this report to be used for purposes of dismissal against Miss Stapleton as she is a fine young woman of excellent moral character, pleasant in manner, neat in dress and habit, kindly in disposition and a conscientious worker, struggling courageously in a not too pleasant environment to make a living for herself and her two adopted children. Miss Stapleton is not to be blamed for this condition of affairs; she tries her best and does a great deal of hard work but she lacks the academic and theoretical training necessary for a successful teacher. Speaking without prejudice the blame rests with the system which appoints unqualified persons to positions where their work is exposed to an inspection which must disclose all its defects.
The real solution of the difficulty would be to secure a qualified teacher to teach the white children of the Reserve. I believe that it would be better for the white children to be taught by themselves not from any feeling of superiority but because the educational presentation must differ, the rate of progress must differ, ideals and standards of life must differ; these and health considerations make separate work advisable.

At present the Anglican missionary obtains a considerable educational grant which pays board and tuition fees for his children in Winnipeg or elsewhere. Why could not that grant be paid to secure a qualified teacher to live on the Reserve and teach his children at home where they could be at all times in the parents charge? It would be possible to secure a qualified teacher for say $600 per annum. This means 10 months teaching. It would be no difficult task for the Indian Agent and the Missionary to obtain a satisfactory building in a locality that would satisfy all. I believe the grant now paid amounts to about $500. The Indian Agent and other white people who might wish to have children educated would have to make up the balance of the salary unless a Special Grant could be obtained from the Dominion Government for this purpose. I know that the grant which the Missionary receives comes from the Anglican authorities over which your Department probably has no control but a recommendation from your Department to the Anglican authorities might assist in securing the change.

There is little hope of assistance from the Provincial Government in the matter of establishing a school on the Reserve but if it were established with a qualified teacher in charge working under the Regulations of the Dept. of Education of the Province there would then be grounds for asking for the Legislative Grant of 75¢ per day paid to schools by the Provincial Government.

I would recommend that future nominations and appointments of teachers to Indian schools be made from persons who are qualified teachers for the Province in which the school is situated. Teachers holding Third and Second Class Professional Certificates may now be secured for from $750 to $800. It is quite possible to obtain a qualified teacher of the requisite religious denomination so that the Church work will not suffer and the education of the children will be much benefitted.

In conclusion I wish to say that the schools of the Peguis and Fisher River Reserves are the best Indian Schools that it has been my pleasure to inspect. The Department of Indian Affairs is to be congratulated on the success which is attending their efforts to educate the Indian children on these Reserves.
A very important factor in the good work being done on these Reserves is the Indian Agent, Mr. McCuish. He has the welfare of the people in his charge very much at heart. He has introduced two valuable innovations into the schools of these two Reserves during the last two years, viz: the Boys & Girls Club Fair, which encourages industrial and educational achievements among the children of these schools, and the introduction of hot lunch material and equipment into all schools in his Reserves. I had the pleasure of his company on my tour of inspection and I found him to be unfailingly kindly, considerate and fair-minded. I am sure that his work and influence must be productive of much good to the people who live on the Reserves under his control.

Your obedient servant,

I have no personal quarrel with Miss Stapleton, she is enthusiastic, and as a church worker, she has few equals, but as a teacher she has missed her calling, she is unable to control the children in the school, as it costs more to keep this school in windows than the other two schools on Peguis, Fisher River, and Jackhead combined. There are more seats broken, and destroyed in this school, than all the other schools combined.

The most advanced Indians in my Agency live in the Centre School district, still we find that when pupils get into grade IV it required from three to four years to get them into grade V, simply because the Church of England use their power and privilege granted them of nominating a teacher to pension off their broken down missionaries.

Personally I am labouring under the great handicap of not having a school education past grade III, and it is my wish that my two boys have a better opportunity for schooling than I have had. This I am duty bound to give them, which I now find I am unable to do, while Indian Agent in this Agency, as I have been very unfortunate with my oldest boy, the only one yet who has attended school, as after coming to Fisher River, I sent him to the Maison Chapple School in Winnipeg. After being there a small time, he contracted Small-Pox. I next sent him to the boys school or St. John's College in Winnipeg, but he was taken down with Pneumonia. I next sent him to Marble Ridge School, when he had to come home with a severe attack of whooping Cough. I will not likely be in the service of the Indian Department, to see the great results that will follow, but I hope the day is not far distant, when the Dept. of Indian Affairs, and they only, shall say, who shall, and who shall not, teach our schools.

Right Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 15th instant, recommending the appointment of Deaconess Winifred Stapleton, at present teacher of the Centre School on the Peguis Reserve, to take charge as teacher of the Oak River Sioux School for the next school year, to succeed the present teacher at that point, Mr. A. Most Rev. Sir:

Dear Mr. McLean,

In further reference to the vacancy in the Central Peguis School, I have the following applicants for the position:

(1) Mrs. Hamilton, an experienced teacher, who has done good work in a number of our schools in foreign settlements. She is highly recommended by her inspectors.

I received your notice & my transference to the Central School, on my return home, receipt it.

Sir:

I have received a copy of Mr. G.W. Bartlett's report in connection with his inspection of Peguis Centre Day School, Fisher River Agency.

In the "General Remarks", he suggests that the teacher be asked to make a list of pupils likely to require clothing for the winter, so that the agencies dealing with this work may have time to deal with such cases before winter sets in.

I do not know if Mr. Bartlett mentioned this fact to Mr. Clarke, the Indian Agent, but I am of the opinion that it was only discussed with the teacher. If such procedure were to be carried out, we would run into a large amount of expense and I doubt if it would greatly improve the attendance. The Peguis Indians are fortunately situated and able to maintain their families equally as well, if not better, than many of the other bands of Indians throughout Manitoba. It would appear as though Mr. Bartlett was not familiar with the circumstances and therefore did not realize what his recommendation would involve.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The children were alert and apparently keenly interested in their work. They speak out clearly and all book work was neat and tidy. The children were clean but none too well clothed.

This trouble arose after the well was drilled at the school over a year ago. Dear Archbishop Sherman:

At the Peguis South School and the Peguis Centre School, in the Fisher River Agency, the enrolment is so large during the current academic year that it is almost impossible for one teacher to handle the school.

Indian Agent Lazenby advises us that he can secure a building at both of the schools mentioned above, which could be opened as a second classroom. We are prepared to open two new classrooms if we can obtain a teacher for each of them. I would therefore appreciate it if you would give this matter your immediate attention and let me know as soon as possible if there is any possibility of securing two teachers. The new teachers would be under the direction of the teachers at present engaged at these two schools. A recent inspector's report indicates that both these teachers are doing good work.

Yours sincerely,

With reference to Mr Philip Phelan's letter, File 136-6-1 of the 10th instant, I beg to say that I have been unable to find anyone locally who would undertake to teach the Peguis Centre School for the balance of the school term, on the resignation of Miss Alice Clarke becoming effective May 1st.

Mr Stanley Boyne, our farming instructor, advised me that probably his sister might take this school to help out, and at my request he wrote to her, and telephoned to her at Arborg, Manitoba. Miss Boyne chanced to call at Inspector Hamilton's office in Winnipeg while I was there on April 22nd, and she was requested to call at the Synod office in Winnipeg, as they would have to recommend her to the Department. However, a few days later, Mr Boyne had a letter from his sister, in which she stated that she would not be taking the school.

In these circumstances therefore, the only alternative is for the school to remain closed, unless the Department has received any word of a teacher from His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land.

P.G. Lazenby

REGINA.—More than 80 per cent. of schools now without teachers will be supplied with student teachers from normal schools under a plan recently developed by education officials and the provincial Department of Education. However, an estimated 60 rural schools in the province will be unable to operate because of the acute shortage of teachers, Deputy Education Minister A. B. Ross said recently.

Mr. Ross pointed out that the teacher shortage is not a situation peculiar to Saskatchewan alone, but that most of the other provinces in the Dominion are having similar difficulties.

The plan, which was worked out by government officials and the principals of the normal schools in Moose Jaw and Saskatoon, provides that rural schools with enrolments of 13 or more will be staffed with normal school students. If student teachers are still available, schools with enrolments of 12 will also be staffed.

Schools which are unable to secure the services of normal school students may adopt one of two alternatives. They may arrange to have their students attend one of the nearby schools already staffed with teachers; or, arrange to have lessons supplied through the government correspondence school. The department of education will pay all costs of supplying courses and of having them marked by competent instructors in the correspondence school.

It is expected that students attending the college of education may be available on or about May 1, for those schools still without teachers. In such cases, arrangements may be made at the discretion of the local school board to have the school in operation during the summer months.

Coolican Takes Over Swift Current Post

REGINA.—P. W. Coolican, poultry specialist, has been transferred to the Agricultural Representative Branch of the provincial government, succeeding W. R. Merryweather as agricultural representative for the Swift Current district, according to a recent public service commission announcement.

Prior to joining the poultry branch in 1946, Mr. Coolican was employed by Canada Packers Limited.

Poultry Grading For Chief Cities

REGINA.—Residents of Regina, Saskatoon, Moose Jaw and Prince Albert will benefit by new regulations concerning the grading of poultry.

According to a recent order-in-council, hotels, restaurants and retail stores will be required to handle only graded poultry after January 1, 1948.

Previously, grading had applied mostly to the eastern export market and had helped build up a strong demand for Saskatchewan raised birds.

A teacher, Miss Phyllis Baron, was appointed to this school in August of this year but she was unable to accept the post because her physician advised her that she would be unable to accept a teaching position for some time. However, she has now fully recovered and we have recently written to her requesting that she report there for duty as soon as possible.

You are, no doubt, aware of the serious situation which exists with regard to the shortage of teachers in Canada. It is understood from the magazine of the Manitoba Teachers' Society that some eighty Manitoba schools were unable to open their doors in September because no teachers were available to conduct classes. We have also been informed that some seven hundred permit teachers are presiding over Manitoba schools and classrooms.

In the "Saskatchewan News", the weekly news bulletin issued by the Bureau of Publications of the Provincial Government of Saskatchewan, we noted that some sixty schools are not operating because of the acute shortage of teachers.

This situation is not peculiar to the

Prairie Provinces but exists in almost every province in the Dominion. Therefore, we feel that our Indian day schools are in a better position relatively than most provincial schools, for we have only eleven schools closed across Canada. Nearly all of these eleven are in the far north and are so isolated as to be most unattractive to teachers. However, the Indians in some areas fail to realize this acute shortage of teachers and have not hesitated to blame the Department for a condition which is caused by factors over which we have no control.

Yours sincerely,

AIRMAIL

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I beg to report that the Peguis Centre Indian Day School is overcrowded, there being about fifty pupils attending fairly regularly, whereas there is accommodation for only about forty pupils, at best.

Would it be possible to secure an additional teacher for this school, and divide the pupils between the two. There is a Church Hall available, which would require to be equipped with desks, etc; as was done at the Peguis South school, where we have two teachers.

I realize the difficulty of securing school teachers, and am constantly having to explain the situation to the Indians, who complain about their children getting no schooling.

P.G. Lazenby,
Sup't: Fisher River Agency.
Ottawa, March 30, 1948.

Dear Archbishop Sherman:

Re: Peguis Centre Indian Day School.

Indian Agent Lazenby advises that this school is now overcrowded as there are some fifty pupils attending regularly. We are prepared to open a second class room if we can secure a teacher.

We realize the difficulty in securing teachers at the present time but thought it advisable to communicate with you in the hope that you can find it possible to nominate a teacher whose services would be satisfactory for the balance of the current academic year. Please let us hear from you as soon as convenient.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan

Sir,

I have received an application from the Revd M. Sanderson, formerly incumbent of the Mission of Peguis in respect to the salary paid his son Mr M.R. Sanderson, teacher of the Peguis Centre School, for the quarter ended September 30th, 1921.

Mr Sanderson states that the cheque sent his son would seem to be for a third of the quarter only.

I beg to advise that Mr M.R. Sanderson is now attending St John's College in Winnipeg and is paying his own expenses and had the firm belief that he would receive salary for the full quarter of September.

I respectfully beg to recommend that the application for the full quarter's salary be given favourable consideration as if Mr Sanderson does not receive this he will be seriously handi-capped.

I have the honour to be your obedient servant

Indian Agent,

Octr. 26th, 1923.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I have received from Miss Stapleton. I do not quite understand the basis of her complaint but I gather that she claims she will be short in her receipts for the quarter ending with September. Will you kindly drop me a line of explanation so that I can satisfy her.

If any injustice has been done to her it ought to be set right for she seems to be a most useful person on the Reserve.

With kind regards, I am,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. Indian Education,
Ottawa, Canada.
Most Reverend Sir:

I have Your Grace's letter of the 26th instant, enclosing a letter from Miss Stapleton, Teacher of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School.

The Department has instituted a change in the method of paying day school teachers. In the past four equal quarterly payments were made - in the future we will pay at the end of each quarter, but on the basis of the teaching months. Heretofore Miss Stapleton has received, in addition to the bonus, four payments of $152.50 during the year. Her salary for this year will be paid as follows:

End of September quarter ....... $ 65.
" December " ........ 125.
" March " ........ 125.
" June " ........ 125.

in other words, on the basis of $65 per teaching month.

I wish to assure Your Grace that I realize this may work a hardship, this fall, on the teachers who have to arrange their personal finances with care, and I have instructed that advances on the December and March quarter earnings be made whenever a teacher intimates a difficult situation because of lack of funds. A cheque for $100 is being directed, under today's date, to be deposited to Miss Stapleton's account at the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Winnipeg. This advance will be deducted from her salary for the December and March quarters.

I am enclosing a copy of this letter, which can be directed to Miss Stapleton, under cover of Your Grace's. Her communication, also, is attached.

I am,

Your Grace's obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Encl.

Most Rev. S. P. Matheson, D. D.,
Archbishop of Rupert's Land,
Bishop's Court,
Winnipeg, Man.

Ottawa, December 4, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, informing the Department that Miss Jennie Wright, whom you were informed by official letter of the 15th ultimo was appointed as teacher of the Peguis South School, desires, instead, to take up duties as teacher at the Peguis Centre School, where she feels that conditions would be more satisfactory.

The Department referred this request to His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land, who concurs in Miss Wright taking charge of the work as teacher at the Centre School. In this connection I have to confirm the following night lettergram to you of today's date:

"Approval granted appointment Miss Wright teacher Peguis Centre School. Arrange with her to begin duties early date."

The salary allowed her will be at the same rate as was to be allowed if she taught at the South School, viz. $90 per teaching month.

It is noted that the teacher's residence at the Centre School is ready and that there are enough furnishings on hand so that the teacher can take up residence. You have already been authorized regarding obtaining the furnishings for the residences at both the Centre and South Schools.

Please advise the Department of the date on which Miss Wright begins duties at the Centre School.

We are informed by His Grace that he expects within a few days to nominate a teacher for the Peguis South School.

H. Templeman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson,
Man.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
Ottawa, December 22nd, 1925.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land stating that Miss Jennie Wright had arrived to take up duties at the Peguis Centre Indian Day School but that the residence was not ready for occupancy. His Grace recommends that, as it was through no fault of her own that she was unable to commence teaching on her arrival, salary be allowed her. The Department will allow Miss Wright salary from the date she arrived at the school, and I shall be pleased if you will inform her accordingly. When she prepares a return for the current quarter, it should be definitely stated thereon the date upon which she arrived to take up duties. It is hoped that the building at this point will be ready by the beginning of the new year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

MEMORANDUM:

Honourable Mr. Meighen,

The Department is in receipt of an account for $581.89 from the Hodgson Trading Company for material supplied for the construction of the new Peguis Indian day school, known as the Central School.

Deputy Superintendent General.
I respectfully beg to direct your attention to vouchers Nos. II71-II72 submitted for materials for the erection of the Peguis Centre School and teacher's quarters.

These two vouchers exceed the estimate as sent you for the whole work and is an error on my part, due to the continual advance in materials and labour. My figure of $1500.00 submitted upon the yearly estimate last fall would have been closer to the correct cost.

I have stopped the work on the Peguis Centre school pending your further instructions as the Indians will not work for less than .50¢ per hour as those who have any knowledge of carpenter work have been receiving that sum during the past winter at Hodgson.

Lumber could not now be bought for the price shown upon the above vouchers and dealers refuse to quote, stating that they are not safe in giving any figures on anything they have not in stock.

With muskrats selling at $5.00 and $6.00 each, the Indians treat with contempt any offer of work at .30¢ per hour. It would perhaps be as well to obtain offers from the Indians to complete the work required to erect the school and teacher's quarters for a stated sum.

I have the honour to be your obedient servant

Y.H. Carter

Articles of agreement made and entered into on this 25th day of June, A.D.1920, between the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, and William Sinclair, Indian, of the Peguis Band of Indians in the Province of Manitoba, it is agreed in manner and form following, viz:

The said William Sinclair covenants and agrees with the Department of Indian Affairs to make, erect, build and finish in a good and substantial and workmanlike manner, on Lot 39: Sec.33: Twp.24 Range 1 West of the Principal Meridian; upon the east side of the Fisher River on the Peguis Indian Reserve in the Province of Manitoba, a school house, to be known as the Peguis Centre School, and a residence for the teacher thereof, agreeably to the specifications herunto annexed, by the first day of September next, upon which date the buildings above mentioned shall be complete and cleaned in readiness for occupation and use.

And the Said Department of Indian Affairs covenants and agrees to supply the said William Sinclair with all materials for the erection and completion of the said Peguis Centre School and Teacher's Residence and to pay him for the work of erecting the said buildings the sum of Two Hundred and Forty Dollars, in lawful money of Canada, as follows:

Advances shall be made to the said William Sinclair from time to time as the work progresses in such sums as is consistent with the value of the work performed; the Department of Indian Affairs to be the sole judge of the value of the work and the prices to be paid therefore. The balance remaining after the last advance, to complete the sum of $240.00, shall be paid to the said William Sinclair as soon after the 1st day of September, next, as the Department of Indian Affairs is satisfied the whole work specified is completed in a satisfactory manner.

June 14th 1922

My Lord Archbishop,

May I ask if you could help us to obtain from the Indian Department a barn for our cow & calf. It means milking outside in all weathers at present. I do not think it would mean much expense for there are plenty of logs lying idle at the Indian agency here (cut for families that did not come up from Selkirk.) We are also urgently needing a well. This spring the whole river ups & downs for a mile on other side of us.
is now fenced off from us. —
And we are the only ones
living this side of the road
within that distance. — And
it means our cow will be
found a mile North or South
of us in her search for water
night & morning — when we
want to milk her. — And for
ourselves it is a great labour
to have to carry up sometimes
as many as fifteen pails of
water from the river on
the other side of the road,
to water the garden & washing
day. — And when we do get it
it is very muddy, as
it is a clay bank trodden down
by the cattle, nearest to us.
Besides one does not like
trespassing on the kindness
of a neighbour, — for ourselves
+ the school children to be always going thro' his fence to fetch water. Besides it is scarcely safe for the smaller children to be playing down there, midday & recess times out of my sight, on the pretext of getting a drink of water.

We have gone to much expense already over the place here; for we were obliged to build a lean-to of rough lumber covered with black paper at the expense of $50 dollars. For a summer kitchen, as the tiny shack of 14 x 18 feet got too hot to have the kitchen stove in, in summer, & we were so cramped for room, we had to have meals in the
So had to build. I don't think we can afford to do any further to it. But lined & ships - slaped, it could be made a pleasing permanent addition to this tiny residence for winter use too.

Also we were told by the temporary agent that it was up to the teacher to provide for the inside fencing when the school fence was put up. So I had to pay 4 dollars more for a load of fence poles to have my garden fenced off from the play ground. And as the Indians employed by the agent said he had finished all he was told to do. When he had put a heavy tripole for a gate. I had to pay him to put a small gate from the
road into the playground, as I could not myself scarcely lift out the heavy loops every time I wanted to go in & out. So I was sure the little children could not do it, but would climb the fence every time. So naturally the small gate I paid for is used by the school children all the time. And as a pole fence is useless to keep dogs & chickens off a garden, on which we have spent much time & labor in order to have vegetables next winter, I had to go to a further expense of ten dollars for two rolls of wire to protect the garden. The children's gardens are unprotected in this respect & have to take their chance. But I see that the south
School on this Reserve has both a barn & a lean-to to the Teacher's residence there. There is no cellar either, so we two women are doing our best to dig one, but it is hard work—digging & carrying out a pailful of earth at a time. But we will have to have one to store our winter supply of potatoes etc. & to keep our milk & butter in the well we have dug so far towards it, right now, this hot weather.

Trusting the I.D. may see their way to helping us.

Believe me

Yours sincerely,

(Deaconess) W.H. Stapleton
(Teacher)
My dear Mr. Scott:

I enclose a letter which I received from Miss Stapleton which speaks for itself. I really think that her request should be granted, especially in the matter of a well and a small stable for her cow. When I visited the Reserve the other day I found that these teachers are doing exceedingly good work, and that the attendance, especially at the North and Central schools, is better than it has ever been in the past. The children, also, appear to be greatly interested in their work.

Now that we have good teachers in these schools it is most important that we should do all in our power to retain them, and they cannot be retained unless they have comfortable quarters. As a result of my experience as Chairman of the Provincial Board of Education I find that it is essential, in the foreign districts, to furnish quarters which are satisfactory. Hoping that your Department will take up the request favorably, and with kindest regards, I am,

Most sincerely yours,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, June 26, 1922.

Most Reverend Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge receipt of Your Grace's letter of the 19th instant, enclosing a communication from Miss Stapleton, Teacher of the Centre School on the Peguis Reserve, in which she requests that a small stable be erected and a well drilled.

In reply I beg to state that we are requesting Mr. Agent McGuish, who has been recently appointed to take charge of the Fisher River Agency, to furnish an estimate of the cost of building a stable and drilling a well and any other work which the teacher desires to have carried out in order to make conditions at this school as comfortable as possible for her.

The Department is aware of the need of wells at all the schools on the Peguis Reserve, but, owing to the cost involved, we have been unable to provide the amount necessary to have the work done. We will, however, do our utmost to have a well drilled at the Centre School.

The Department is pleased to note that the teachers on the Peguis Reserve are doing good work, that the attendance is better than it has ever been in the past and that the children are beginning to take more interest in their work.

Ottawa, June 26, 1922.

Sir:

His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land has forwarded a communication to the Department from Miss Stapleton, Teacher of the Centre School on the Peguis Reserve, in which she requests that a log stable be erected. She states that it is necessary for her to keep a cow to provide milk, and that a stable or barn is needed. She further states that she does not consider the putting up of a suitable stable would entail much expense, as there are plenty of logs lying idle at the agency, which could be used for the purpose.

I have to request that you will state the cost of having a small log stable erected and if there are any suitable logs on hand which could be utilized. The Department is anxious to provide this building, in order that the teacher can keep a cow during the coming winter. It is considered that a barn or stable, suitable for the purpose, could be erected at very little expense, having in view the utilizing of the logs which the teacher states are available.

Miss Stapleton also states that a well is urgently required, as facilities for obtaining water from the river are most unsatisfactory. The question of providing wells for each of the schools on the Peguis Reserve was under consideration by the late Agent, Mr. Carter, but owing to the expenses involved in drilling them, no action was taken in the matter. I have to request that you will furnish your views as to the best means of having a well drilled at the Centre School, and state approximately what you consider the cost would be. Please state if a well drilling outfit is available and if tenders could be obtained from a number of persons having this equipment for the drilling of a well. You should give as full information as possible regarding the best method to be used in having a well drilled.

The teacher further states that she has gone to much expense in having a lean-to put up for a summer kitchen. This was built of rough lumber, covered with black building paper, and she states it should be ship-lapped, which would make it a permanent addition to the residence. Please state what it would cost to complete this lean-to; and, if Miss Stapleton can furnish itemized accounts in duplicate, covering the amount she herself has expended, the Department will consider reimbursing her for the expenditure she has already incurred. If she can furnish these accounts, you should certify and forward them to the Department, when consideration will be given to the payment.

M. McCuish, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent
The Halfway P.O.,
Man.

Any other repairs required by the teacher, so as to make the conditions at this school comfortable should be stated, and the approximate cost of the work should be given.

I have to request that you will visit this school at an early date, inquire into all the above matters and furnish the Department with a full report, stating your views as to the best means of having any work which you would recommend carried out, and the approximate cost of the same. Sir,

In reply to your letter #136-65 of June 26th, I wish to report that I visited Miss Stapleton at Centre School Peguis Reserve & inquired into the various different matters mentioned in your letter.

Re the Stabel twelve feet wide sixteen feet long seven feet high using an eight foot rafter by using the logs & shingles, which we have on hand at the Agency leaving the sheathing on roof & nails to be bought in town the stabel completed would cost approximately eighty five dollars work included.

Re well for School Centre School Peguis "I quite agree with Miss Stapleton that a well required, at this School, there is only one well drilling outfit in this district, owned by one Mr. Beards at Fisher Branch his price is four dollars per foot he finds everything the only basis I can take for an estimate of the cost would be from the well here at the Fisher river Agency is one hundred & fifty seven feet deep at four dollars per foot would be six hundred & twenty eight dollars.

Re lean to for Summer Kitchen to complete this building I would recommend shingling the walls using the shingles from this Agency which it would take about two & a quarter thousand with an additional ten dollars for fever board & would make a very comfortable building Miss Stapleton will furnish limited amounts in duplicate covering the amount she herself has expended.

Re lean fencing I inspected the fence mentioned & find the ten dollars for the two rolls of chicken wire was required to protect her garden from dogs & cattle belonging to the band on this reserve.

The plaster of the School building needs repairing in a few places which could be done at the same time as the School stable is being done.

OTTAWA, July 25th, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, furnishing an estimate of the cost of building a stable at the Peguis Centre School.

It is noted that by using the logs and shingles which are on hand at the Agency, and purchasing the sheeting for the roof and the nails required, this stable could be completed at a cost of approximately $85.00. I have, therefore, to request that you will make the necessary arrangements to have this stable erected. It should be of the dimensions mentioned by you, viz: 16' long, 12' wide and 7' high with an 8' rafter. You may purchase the sheeting for the roof and the nails required. It will be necessary to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and the material required over and above that on hand should be purchased from the dealer quoting the lowest price.

Regarding the drilling of a well, I beg to say that, owing to the cost involved, we are unable to authorize this work at the present time. Our funds for Indian education are limited, and have been assigned, and we will have no money available for the drilling of a well. The teacher will have to arrange to obtain the water required from the river.

Regarding the building of a summer kitchen to the teacher's residence, I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work carried out. You may use the shingles required, which are on hand at the Agency, and you may purchase any other material required, in order to complete this summer kitchen and make a satisfactory job of the work. It will be necessary to obtain competitive prices in making all purchases of the material.

You should arrange for competent labour in the erection of both the stable and the summer kitchen.

The plaster in the school building should be repaired when the other work is being done.

When all this work has been completed, you should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the material required, as well as labour returns, in duplicate, for the labour employed. Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School, and requesting that certain repairs be made to the floor in the schoolroom.

In reply I beg to say that the school material will be ordered from the Government Stationery Office to be sent to the teacher's address. A football will be ordered and forwarded from here.

You may purchase an inexpensive ladder of sufficient length to reach the roof of the school building. No undue expenditure should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the cost of the ladder.

Regarding the floor, I beg to say that Mr. Bartlett, Provincial School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of this school, states regarding the conditions of the school building, as follows:

"Floor unsupported. Very shaky. This is a comparatively new building and should be in good condition. Interior should be finished in light color on account of the light requirements."

Mr. Commissioner Graham, in forwarding this report, states that the floor should be repaired and placed in good condition and the painting done next spring. We note that you do not recommend laying a new floor on top of the present one, but that supports are required. As soon as weather conditions permit you should arrange to have posts with proper supports placed under the floor, in order to prevent it springing. We note that you estimate this work at $10. This matter will be left in your hands to have the necessary repairs made in the spring, and the work should be done as cheaply as possible.

You should also furnish a report as to the cost of having the interior painted a lighter color and if it is decided to have this work done it can be carried out at the time the repairs to the floor are being made.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters 136-5-5 of the 15th inst., letter 136-6-5 of the 16th inst., and letter 136-4-5 of the 17th inst.

In reference to improvements to the North, Centre, and South Indian Day Schools on the Peguis Reserve, and in reply would recommend that Mr. Inspector Bartlett's recommendations as to improvements at each school be adopted as I am unable to offer any suggestions for any further improvements.

Referring to the floor of the North School acting on instructions contained in letter 136-4-5 dated Dec 14th 1922 I had a new floor laid in this school, for which the voucher was issued on Jan the 4th.

For making the alterations to the windows in the North School I would estimate the cost at twenty dollars and for washing and whitewashing the ceiling at seven dollars, with reference to the South School for laying new floor, washing and whitewashing the ceiling and rearranging the windows at forty dollars; the Centre School estimated cost of supporting the floor, washing and whitewashing the ceiling at fifteen dollars; the windows in this school are also on the North and the South which has the same evil effect as in the other schools, and I would recommend that the North windows be closed up, and an additional window be put in the South side. For the ceilings in all the three schools I would recommend whitewash in preference to paint for the work can be performed better by an amateur than painting, also it would be cheaper to give it a fresh coat each year, at the same time the interior is being whitewashed. Any new material required for any of the above work with the exception of lime and nails can be furnished from stock in store at the Agency.

As the South School is the most urgent I beg to suggest that this work be done during the Easter Holidays.

Referring to the last paragraph of letter 136-5-5 of the 15th inst. referring to towels and drinking cups for use in the Indian Bay Schools this suggestion is well taken, and with the co-operation of the teachers this should prove very beneficial, and I have more than once remarked to the teachers that the single towel and drinking cup was an up-to-date disease risk. I have asked all our local stores for tenders on 8½ dozen cups and 8½ dozen pairs of towels. All of which is respectfully submitted.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I have the honour to be,
Your obedient servant,

M. McCuish,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 7, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the improvements required to the schools on the Peguis Reserve.

With reference to the Centre School, it is noted that you estimate the cost of supporting the floor, washing and whitewashing the ceiling would be approximately $15.00. You may take the necessary action, during the coming Easter holidays, or as soon as weather conditions permit, to have the floor put in a good state of repair by placing proper supports underneath. It is considered that the ceiling and the interior of this building should be whitewashed. The windows on the north side may be closed up and an additional window put in on the south side of the building.

All the above work should be completed as cheaply as possible. We note that you can supply all the materials needed, with the exception of the lime and nails. These, you may purchase and have delivered, also, if necessary, a window frame and glass for the window on the south side.

When the work has been completed, please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, for the expenses incurred at this school, separately from any work performed at the other schools. Also, in your correspondence in future each school should be dealt with in a separate communication.

We note that you are calling for tenders for the supplying of drinking cups and towels, as recommended by the Public School Inspector. When these have been purchased, please arrange to have them delivered to each of the schools on the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

The teacher informs me she would rather calcalmine inside the house herself, than be bothered with a man. The approximate cost, therefore, would be 5 or 6 dollars for calcalmine and brush.

I do not feel justified in recommending the outside of the residence be painted, for the reason, that the residencies of the other two teachers on the Reserve, are not painted. There has been more money expended on improvements at the Centre School, than the other two schools combined during the past 10 months and the repairs to the Fisher River Day School are going to be a heavy drain, on the funds for Indian education, this year.

I have the honour to be,
your obedient servant,

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

Miss Brandon, Travelling Nurse, in a report on her inspection of the Fisher River Agency, has drawn attention to a number of pupils at the schools on the Peguis Reserve who require medical attention. She states that she has advised the medical officer as to the attention that should be given in each case.

Miss Brandon recommends that a drum be attached to the stove pipes in each of the schools on the Peguis Reserve, as this would provide a more regular and even heat and would greatly assist in getting the rooms heated and keeping them in that condition. If you consider that the arrangement suggested by the Nurse would be of benefit in keeping the schools warm, you may arrange for the purchase and installation of a drum for the stove pipes in each school.

Miss Brandon has also suggested that, if possible, a hot drink be provided to the pupils of each of the schools during the noon hour, especially during the severe cold weather, as so many of them come from a distance. If the teachers will arrange to prepare and serve a hot drink, and if they have facilities for doing so, you may purchase a small quantity of cocoa, tea and sugar, also 1 dozen granite-ware mugs and a large saucepan for preparing the cocoa. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and you should purchase the quantity of materials required in the preparation of the hot drink sufficient to last for each school during the balance of the winter or until the end of April, next, only. Please consult the teachers as soon as possible and, if they will prepare and serve this hot drink, you should purchase the supplies required. The children could, no doubt, bring any milk required from their homes. The Nurse states that the pupils each carried a noon day lunch which was quite a credit to the Indian parents.

I shall be pleased to hear later as to the arrangements you have been able to make regarding the serving of a hot drink at noon.

Your obedient servant,

M. McCuish, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Halfway P.O.,
Man.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing a requisition for supplies for the use of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School.

Sir:

Ottawa, April 28th, 1927.

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School, states as follows concerning the school building:

"The school building is the worst on the Reserve. Log. A very poor building and its upkeep seems to be sadly neglected - walls with chinking falling out and dirty. They are supposed to be whitewashed but it could not have been for some time. The building, in every way, is far from what it should be. In addition to this, it is not kept in a tidy condition. The surroundings outside are not neat or tidy.

A new building should be erected or, at the very least, the present one given a thorough overhauling and repairing. Siding inside and out would help matters.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you stating what action you would recommend be taken in having this building renovated and placed in a satisfactory condition. I may say that we have no funds available for the erection of a new building, but it is considered that the repairs, etc., absolutely necessary should be made to the present building. In forwarding your report as to the work you would recommend be carried out, you should state the approximate cost involved.

We note that the Inspector states that this building is not kept in a tidy condition. Please state whether this is due to carelessness on the part of the teacher.

When we have your report giving full particulars as to the repairs and renovation you would advise be made and information as to the cost involved, consideration will then be given to authorizing having the work done during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary."

Sir,

Re Repairs,
Peguis Centre School.

Replying to your letter #136-6-5 of April 28th with reference to the condition of the building containing the Peguis Centre School, I beg to report as follows:

The school building was chinked and whitewashed in 1925 but a very poor quality of lime was used and work was not superintended and was poorly executed. In September, 1926, I wrote to Regina for authority to carry out mudding and whitewashing of all schools but letter was overlooked at the Commissioner's office and, when authority was received, the winter had set in and it was then too late to carry out the work.

I have gone over the building thoroughly and beg to recommend that it be sheeted inside with V-joint. The seating will be required only on the walls as the school has already a V-joint ceiling. It will require approximately 1500 ft. of V-joint and the cost of this material will be about $90.00. It will also take about 500 lineal feet of 1 x 2 firing on which to nail V-joint, cost of which will be about $10.00. The wall on one side of the building is buckling slightly and I would further recommend that this be strengthened by placing a 4 in. tim rod across the building. The total cost of all this work inclusive of labour will be in the neighbourhood of $200.00. May authority be granted to have the work carried out?

With reference to the statement of the Inspector that the school is not kept in a tidy condition, I beg to advise that this is no fault of the teachers. The care and arrangement of school furniture is good and the school is well scrubbed once each month. The dilapidated condition of the walls and the chinking falling out on the floor contributes towards giving the schoolroom an untidy appearance. In addition, the school is situated close to a swamp and, during the greater part of the present spring, the school grounds have been under water.

I would also recommend that V-joint be painted white after it is put on, that the outside of the school building be re-chinked and whitewashed, and that toilets be moved and new vaults dug. An additional $25.00 will cover this work.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman,
The Department of Indian Affairs Indian Agent,

Sir,

Re Drainage,
Peguis Centre School.

Replying to your letter #136-6-5 of July 12th past with reference to drainage of the grounds of the Peguis Centre School, I beg to advise that I have delayed action in this matter for the reason that, up until the present, the condition of the ground rendered it impossible to work with a team and scraper in digging the necessary ditch to drain the grounds. To carry off the water will take a large ditch and digging by hand would be an expensive operation.

I have had Mr. Patterson, Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Branch, who is up here on the matter of drainage possibilities of the Peguis hay meadows, survey a ditch for drainage of the grounds at the Peguis Centre School and take the necessary levels. The ditch will require to be 600 ft. long, this distance being the full length of the fence on the north side of the school property, with an average depth of 3.3 ft. and, at its eastern end, will be a hand dug lateral following the eastern fence of the school property the length of which will be determined when water is flowing through the land ditch. The southern side of the school property is on high ground, therefore, it will not be necessary to dig a ditch on that side.

The ditch will be 8'6" wide at the top and 2' wide at the bottom, giving an average width of 5.3' for the purposes of calculation of yardage of soil to be excavated. The cubic yardage is as follows:

\[
\frac{2.3 \times 5.3 \times 600}{27} = 385.4 \text{ cu. yds}
\]

equals 385.4 cu. yds for purpose of estimate of cost.

I would estimate the cost at about $20 per yard which would make the total cost approximately $80.

The ground is now dry and fit for working and I would recommend that the work be carried out as soon as possible. Without this ditch, there will be trouble from flooding every spring and after all heavy rains. Drainage will also remove the unpleasant stagnant odour from the swamp which permeates the school buildings.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman,
Indian Agent,
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

In detail, the work carried out on the school was as follows:

A dado, 4 ft. high, was built around the walls of the school with quarter-round at bottom of dado and 4 x 4 cove and 3 in. ledge at top. It was the original intention to sheet the whole log wall with V-joint but, in view of the fact that upper logs were very uneven in surface and would require to be reshingled before putting on V-joint - a slow and expensive task - it was decided that the dado was preferable. The intervening log wall between the top of the dado and the ceiling was well chinked and whitewashed. Seven window frames were taken out, resawn and repaired and replaced and also two door frames. Two blackboards were also reframed. A part of the floor was taken up and new floor supports were put in and floor relaid. Posts of the ceiling, which was falling, were re-nailed. A platform was built at the end of the school for the teacher's desk, the size being 6 x 16 feet, and a cupboard was also built - size 1½ x 4 x 6 for books and school material. Posts were palced on outside walls of building and a truss rod from these posts across the inside of the school - this to prevent further buckling of the log walls. All broken school desks were repaired and exterior of building was resmeled and whitewashed. Interior woodwork was painted - pearl grey with darker shades of grey on mouldings and window and door frames. Interior of school porch was also painted. All toilets were moved and repaired and new vaults dug and these together with stable, were well whitewashed. In addition all weeds and grass was cut on the enclosure surrounding the school.

I may say that the dado has made a considerable improvement in the appearance of the school and I would recommend that the interior of the Peguis North and Peguis South Schools be improved in the same manner.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman, Indian agent.

Sir,— Re Drainage Ditch — Peguis Centre School.

With reference to Voucher No. 222 for the amount of $22.25 covering the above-stated expenditure, going forward this date, I beg to advise as follows:

The ditch was dug to its full depth for a distance of 450 feet. On the last 150 feet of the ditch — the upper inlet portion — water was struck at a depth of 1 foot and the ditch was dug on this portion to a depth of only 18 inches. The stickiness of the soil and the difficulty in cleaning scrapers at this depth made the task a slow and difficult one and would have incurred considerable expense. Under these circumstances, I stopped the work. I anticipate that, when the snow melts in the spring, the force of water running in the upper portion of the ditch will cause considerable cutting and increase its depth. I have left a number of ridges in the upper portion to cause rapids when the water runs, which will, I think, have the effect of causing considerable cutting.

In the autumn of 1928, given a dry fall, the ditch can be deepened— if necessary, and the lateral dug. In any case, the ditch as it is at present, will have the effect of keeping dry that portion of the ground in the vicinity of the residence and school which has always in the past been a swamp.

I may inform you that the above-stated ditch is that shown by Mr. Paterson, Engineer of the Water Power & Reclamation Branch, Department of the Interior, on his plan accompanying report on drainage of the Peguis Hay Meadows, marked as 3B in Area No. 3.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.
REGINA, SASK., Nov. 21st, 1927.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on
the schools of the Fisher River Agency.

PEGUIS CENTRE SCHOOL.

I visited this school November 1st, and
found 18 children present - 8 girls and 10 boys. The
roll called for 24. I believe the attendance at this
school is much improved and I have no doubt that with the
present teacher, we will see a still further improve-
ment.

The grades are all low, from 1 to 3.
However, the children appeared well along in their work.
The reading was fair, spelling and arithmetic good. Their
exercise books were tidy. I believe these children will
show advancement under Miss Fairservice.

The children were quite well clothed and
were all clean, with their hair nicely combed. They were
very respectful and the discipline was excellent. All
children were kept busy, whether up in class or otherwise.

This school is built of logs and each year
requires a great deal of repair. It was nicely white-
washed and consequently appeared quite cheerful.

The residence provided for the teacher might
well be called a "shack". There are only two rooms habit-
able in the winter. The lean-to additions are of little
use, even in the summer, and certainly do not add to its
appearance. I believe a new residence could be built quite
reasonably.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
PEGUIS CENTRE SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

reasonably, and it would certainly be an inducement to hold a good, qualified teacher. At present this house needs painting outside, but I think it a mistake to put any further expense on such a building.

Miss Fairservice has recently come to this school. She is a qualified teacher with experience and certainly appears to understand her work. I believe we will see good work carried on and I have no doubt, when next inspected, the results from Miss Fairservice's efforts will be evident.

EXTRACT FROM NURSE BRANDON'S REPORT.

Fisher River Indian Agency,
Hodgson, Man., Feb. 29, 1928.

I have the honor of submitting a report of my visit in Peguis Centre Day School.

At noonday lunch time, these little ones, who also carry some lunch with them, are provided with a cup of hot cocoa, prepared by the teacher. Occasionally one or two pupils bring a bottle of milk which is added to the cocoa. Powdered milk, if such could be allowed, would be very good for making the cocoa much nicer.

(Sgd.) Annie T. Brandon,
T. Nurse.
Ottawa, April 5th, 1928.

Sir:

Miss Brandon, Travelling Nurse, in a report on her visit to the Peguis Centre Indian Day School, recommends that powdered milk be supplied for the pupils' midday lunch. She states that the pupils carry some lunch with them, and are provided with a cup of hot cocoa, prepared by the teacher, and that powdered milk, if such were allowed, would make the cocoa much nicer.

You may arrange to supply a small quantity of Dri-Milk for the use of this school. An account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred. I shall be pleased if you will give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Ass't Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Re: Well - Peguis Centre School.

In the Estimates for the present Fiscal Year I placed an item of $200.00 for the purpose of drilling a well at the Peguis Centre School. This well is essential as, at present, the Teacher has to get her drinking water from the river or from the old well on the property.

The cost of this well will be in the neighbourhood of $200.00, the price per foot being $2.00, inclusive of casing.

May authority be granted to proceed with this work?

Sir,

Re Desks - Peguis Centre School.

Replying to your letter of the 28th instant with reference to complaint by the E. N. Moyer Co., Ltd., Toronto, that the desks purchased by me recently for the above-named school were not all Canadian manufacture and in reply to your query in the closing paragraph thereof, I beg to advise that the desks in question were purchased from the Canada Seating Co., of Winnipeg and the standards of these desks are of plate steel.

Under authority of your letter of November 8, 1925, I called for tenders from all firms named by you thereon, specifying that desks must have plate steel standards. The E. N. Moyer Co. of Winnipeg quoted on their New Empire Desks, stating that these were not plate steel but semi-steel. You will understand that semi-steel means that a part of the standard, the greater part which takes the stress, is of cast iron. I have referred to the Britannica and can find no trace of a material known as semi-steel, in fact, from what I read, it is not possible to blend cast iron and steel. It is apparent, therefore, that semi-steel consists of cast iron and steel joined as separate entities.

My reason for recommending plate steel desks is, that, the experience with semi-steel or cast iron standards in the schools at this Agency is that they are too easily broken. Practically every standard on the old desks at the Peguis Centre School, which were of cast iron, was broken and two of the standards of New Empire desks supplied for the Fisher River Day School are already broken. Plate steel standards may, under great stress, be bent but it is practically impossible to break them. In view of the fact that we have at this Agency desks supplied by the E. N. Moyer Co. last year on which the standards are already broken, which desks are identical with those quoted by them recently, it is apparent that these standards are inferior to plate steel.

I do not know whether the standards of the desks supplied by the Canada Seating Co. are of Canadian or United States manufacture. There is no mark on the standard to show where they are made.

If these standards are made in the U.S. as claimed by the E. N. Moyer Co. and the standards on the desks quoted by them are of equivalent durability, they have a right to contention. If, however, as happens to be the case from experience with their product, their standards are inferior as regards durability, I do not see that they have a right to contention.
I might mention that, as I received no instructions in your letter of November 5th to specify desks of Canadian manufacture, your letter simply stating that I was to place the order with the firm quoting the lowest price, it never entered my head to specify Canadian manufacture.

I give hereunder quotations received from the various firms asked to tender:

Items: 1 Teacher's Sanitary Desk; Plate Steel Pupils Desks - 6 Single Desks No. 2; 6 No. 3; 6 No. 4; 6 No. 5; 6 Rears No. 2; 6 Fronts No. 5.

Western Seating Co., Winnipeg. $336.50
(Globe Steel Desks - Distributors for the Globe Steel Furniture Co., Waterloo, Ontario, so the standards may possibly be of Canadian Manufacture)

E. N. Moyer Co., Ltd., Winnipeg. $246.30
(New Empire Desks - Semi-Steel or Cast Iron Standards - Lowest tender, but not accepted for reason that standards were not steel)

Canada Seating Co., Winnipeg. $279.85
(Plate Steel Desks. This company are official Distributors for the Saskatchewan School Trustees Assoc. This tender was accepted, it being the lowest for steel standard desks.)

Christie School Supply, Ltd., Brandon. $300.00
(Plate Steel Desks. Pamphlet accompanying their tender shows that standards are made in the U.S.)

I might mention that the Canada Seating Co. stated in their letter that the steel desks they supplied were the same as those supplied recently to the Indian School at the Hobema Agency.

I beg to state that the desks supplied by the Canada Seating Co. are of excellent quality. I have given the steel standards a good test and would say that these will last indefinitely and that we will have no more trouble with broken standards.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo No. 136-6-5, informing me that the Public School Inspector in a report on his recent inspection of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School makes the following remarks on the new school building which was erected last summer,

"The school building gives one the impression of being cramped. The matter of making the ceiling a foot higher and removing the partitions between the schoolroom proper and the entrance walls might be considered."

It is really hard to understand an intelligent School Inspector making comments of this kind. The taking away of the walls would throw the doors right open into the classroom and there would be no vestibule. This, of course, is impracticable and you would not find a school in the provinces of Manitoba or Saskatchewan built on these lines. With regard to the suggestion that the ceiling be made a foot higher, there is no necessity for this; the ceiling is now 10 ft. high, which provides ample air space. This school, and five others like it that were built by the Department, were not put up without giving every consideration to the requirements. As a matter of fact, the plans were borrowed from the Department of Education for this province and the buildings were erected on exactly the same lines as the plans submitted called for. Were not these plans sent down to you-

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
down to you for perusal, not in connection with this particular school, but before we started to use them? I would say that there is no reason at all for making any change and I should like to impress upon the Department very strongly the fact that we would not put up a building without giving the question of air space full consideration. If you will refer to the last report written by Mr. Kirkpatrick you will note that there were only 14 children on the roll at the time of his inspection, so with that number they had twice as much air space as the children have in our modern schools anywhere. When this school plan was decided upon it was figured that it would look after the requirements of thirty children, and it will be a long time before there will be thirty pupils at this school, judging from the number that have attended Day School on this reserve in the past.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

Reference charges on the attached Voucher No. 42 - $18.60, I beg to advise that, during the past winter, a fire broke out in the residence of the teacher at the Peguis South School. Miss Wright, the teacher, was ill in bed at the time and it was some time before she could obtain assistance in putting out the fire.

The cause of the fire was condensation of creosote in the stove pipe at the elbow where it goes through one of the partitions. The elbow was filled up with the creosote from the wood and this caught fire and the heat from the pipe ignited the ten-test around the thimble, burning ceiling above and a large hole through partition between rooms. The stove pipe runs the full length of the building and it is a difficult matter to prevent formation of creosote from the wood. Stove pipes are now taken down twice per month and cleaned out, which will prevent any fire in pipes in future.

Repairs were executed and the brick casing surrounding the stove pipe, where it enters the partition, was made larger. An asbestos covering was placed in aperture and ten test was cut clear of thimble. There is little danger of fire in the future. Material for repairs, ten-test, panel strip, asbestos, nails, etc., had to be obtained from Winnipeg. The freight bill is attached hereto but I have not received invoice for material although I have twice asked for this.

In this connection, I would recommend that Pryene Fire Extinguishers be provided set in brackets in each schoolroom and in each teacher's residence on the Peguis Reserve. As there are three schools and three residences on the Peguis Reserve, six of these extinguishers would be required, together with a reserve supply of solution for refilling.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman, Indian Agent.

Sir:-

I enclose for payment two vouchers forwarded by Mr. H. Templeman, Indian Agent at Fisher River, in connection with the drilling of a well at the Peguis Centre School, regarding which I would refer to Department authority 136-6-5, dated 3rd October last, and my letter on the subject dated 22nd October. The vouchers are as follows:

No. 28 - Robinson Alamo Limited $18.90
No. 29 - H. Templeman .95

Mr. Templeman offers an explanation in regard to these expenditures by stating that after the well had been drilled water flowed over the top, and, notwithstanding authority given him last November to purchase a pump, he did not do so, stating he was advised to wait in order to determine from the nature of the flow what style of pump was required. He therefore plugged the well, but in February apparently the pressure of water removed the plug and the purchases, which the vouchers represent, cover additional material that he procured to hold back the water until the spring. These were expenditures, of course, which should have been included in the estimates for the last fiscal year, and, as the transaction took place in February, it is not understood why Mr. Templeman did not submit them before for payment. As I have previously mentioned, he is lacking in business capacity, and should long ago have reported the situation. When the Inspector visits this Agency the matter will be further looked into.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, April 23rd, 1930.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from the teacher of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School for classroom supplies and supplies for the preparing and serving of the midday lunch, also supplies for cleaning purposes.

In reply I have to say that an order is being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the classroom supplies considered necessary.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

1 Double boiler, enamel (for cooking purposes), 2 Mirrors (inexpensive),
30 Dessert spoons (inexpensive), 30 Graniteware cups,
1 Enamel ladle, 2 Wash basins,
1 Large spoon, 2 Scrubbing brushes,
3 Cakes Bon Ami, 1 Tin stove polish,
14 Yds. cheesecloth, 2 Brooms,
1 Galv. iron pail, 18 Cakes carbolic soap,
1 Stove brush.

While serviceable articles should be supplied, it is not intended that any large expense be incurred.

After these supplies have been delivered, you should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The department will send 30 tooth brushes to the teacher for the use of the pupils.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Indian Agent,
Hodgson,
Man.
